base.dists.bernoulli.quantile:
base.dists.bernoulli.quantile( r, p )
    Evaluates the quantile function for a Bernoulli distribution with success
    probability `p` at a probability `r`.

    If `r < 0` or `r > 1`, the function returns `NaN`.

    If `p < 0` or `p > 1`, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided `NaN` as any argument, the function returns `NaN`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    r: number
        Input probability.

    p: number
        Success probability.

    Returns
    -------
    out: number
        Evaluated quantile function.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.bernoulli.quantile( 0.8, 0.4 )
    1
    > y = base.dists.bernoulli.quantile( 0.5, 0.4 )
    0
    > y = base.dists.bernoulli.quantile( 0.9, 0.1 )
    0

    > y = base.dists.bernoulli.quantile( -0.2, 0.1 )
    NaN

    > y = base.dists.bernoulli.quantile( NaN, 0.8 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.bernoulli.quantile( 0.4, NaN )
    NaN

    > y = base.dists.bernoulli.quantile( 0.5, -1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.bernoulli.quantile( 0.5, 1.5 )
    NaN


base.dists.bernoulli.quantile.factory( p )
    Returns a function for evaluating the quantile function of a Bernoulli
    distribution with success probability `p`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    p: number
        Success probability.

    Returns
    -------
    quantile: Function
        Quantile function.

    Examples
    --------
    > var myquantile = base.dists.bernoulli.quantile.factory( 0.4 );
    > var y = myquantile( 0.4 )
    0
    > y = myquantile( 0.8 )
    1
    > y = myquantile( 1.0 )
    1

base.dists.beta.Beta:
base.dists.beta.Beta( [α, β] )
    Returns a beta distribution object.

    Parameters
    ----------
    α: number (optional)
        First shape parameter. Must be greater than `0`. Default: `1.0`.

    β: number (optional)
        Second shape parameter. Must be greater than `0`. Default: `1.0`.

    Returns
    -------
    beta: Object
        Distribution instance.

    beta.alpha: number
        First shape parameter. If set, the value must be greater than `0`.

    beta.beta: number
        Second shape parameter. If set, the value must be greater than `0`.

    beta.entropy: number
        Read-only property which returns the differential entropy.

    beta.kurtosis: number
        Read-only property which returns the excess kurtosis.

    beta.mean: number
        Read-only property which returns the expected value.

    beta.median: number
        Read-only property which returns the median.

    beta.mode: number
        Read-only property which returns the mode.

    beta.skewness: number
        Read-only property which returns the skewness.

    beta.stdev: number
        Read-only property which returns the standard deviation.

    beta.variance: number
        Read-only property which returns the variance.

    beta.cdf: Function
        Evaluates the cumulative distribution function (CDF).

    beta.logcdf: Function
        Evaluates the natural logarithm of the cumulative distribution function
        (CDF).

    beta.logpdf: Function
        Evaluates the natural logarithm of the probability density function
        (PDF).

    beta.mgf: Function
        Evaluates the moment-generating function (MGF).

    beta.pdf: Function
        Evaluates the probability density function (PDF).

    beta.quantile: Function
        Evaluates the quantile function at probability `p`.

    Examples
    --------
    > var beta = base.dists.beta.Beta( 1.0, 1.0 );
    > beta.alpha
    1.0
    > beta.beta
    1.0
    > beta.entropy
    0.0
    > beta.kurtosis
    -1.2
    > beta.mean
    0.5
    > beta.median
    0.5
    > beta.mode
    NaN
    > beta.skewness
    0.0
    > beta.stdev
    ~0.289
    > beta.variance
    ~0.0833
    > beta.cdf( 0.8 )
    0.8
    > beta.logcdf( 0.8 )
    ~-0.223
    > beta.logpdf( 1.0 )
    0.0
    > beta.mgf( 3.14 )
    ~7.0394
    > beta.pdf( 1.0 )
    1.0
    > beta.quantile( 0.8 )
    0.8
base.dists.beta.cdf:
base.dists.beta.cdf( x, α, β )
    Evaluates the cumulative distribution function (CDF) for a beta distribution
    with first shape parameter `α` and second shape parameter `β` at a value
    `x`.

    If provided `NaN` as any argument, the function returns `NaN`.

    If `α <= 0` or `β <= 0`, the function returns `NaN`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    x: number
        Input value.

    α: number
        First shape parameter.

    β: number
        Second shape parameter.

    Returns
    -------
    out: number
        Evaluated CDF.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.beta.cdf( 0.5, 1.0, 1.0 )
    0.5
    > y = base.dists.beta.cdf( 0.5, 2.0, 4.0 )
    ~0.813
    > y = base.dists.beta.cdf( 0.2, 2.0, 2.0 )
    ~0.104
    > y = base.dists.beta.cdf( 0.8, 4.0, 4.0 )
    ~0.967
    > y = base.dists.beta.cdf( -0.5, 4.0, 2.0 )
    0.0
    > y = base.dists.beta.cdf( 1.5, 4.0, 2.0 )
    1.0

    > y = base.dists.beta.cdf( 2.0, -1.0, 0.5 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.beta.cdf( 2.0, 0.5, -1.0 )
    NaN

    > y = base.dists.beta.cdf( NaN, 1.0, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.beta.cdf( 0.0, NaN, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.beta.cdf( 0.0, 1.0, NaN )
    NaN

base.dists.beta.logcdf:
base.dists.beta.logcdf( x, α, β )
    Evaluates the natural logarithm of the cumulative distribution function
    (CDF) for a beta distribution with first shape parameter `α` and second
    shape parameter `β` at a value `x`.

    If provided `NaN` as any argument, the function returns `NaN`.

    If `α <= 0` or `β <= 0`, the function returns `NaN`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    x: number
        Input value.

    α: number
        First shape parameter.

    β: number
        Second shape parameter.

    Returns
    -------
    out: number
        Evaluated logCDF.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.beta.logcdf( 0.5, 1.0, 1.0 )
    ~-0.693
    > y = base.dists.beta.logcdf( 0.5, 2.0, 4.0 )
    ~-0.208
    > y = base.dists.beta.logcdf( 0.2, 2.0, 2.0 )
    ~-2.263
    > y = base.dists.beta.logcdf( 0.8, 4.0, 4.0 )
    ~-0.034
    > y = base.dists.beta.logcdf( -0.5, 4.0, 2.0 )
    -Infinity

base.dists.betaprime.BetaPrime:
base.dists.betaprime.BetaPrime( [α, β] )
    Returns a beta prime distribution object.

    Parameters
    ----------
    α: number (optional)
        First shape parameter. Must be greater than `0`. Default: `1.0`.

    β: number (optional)
        Second shape parameter. Must be greater than `0`. Default: `1.0`.

    Returns
    -------
    betaprime: Object
        Distribution instance.

    betaprime.alpha: number
        First shape parameter. If set, the value must be greater than `0`.

    betaprime.beta: number
        Second shape parameter. If set, the value must be greater than `0`.

    betaprime.kurtosis: number
        Read-only property which returns the excess kurtosis.

    betaprime.mean: number
        Read-only property which returns the expected value.

    betaprime.mode: number
        Read-only property which returns the mode.

    betaprime.skewness: number
        Read-only property which returns the skewness.

    betaprime.stdev: number
        Read-only property which returns the standard deviation.

    betaprime.variance: number
        Read-only property which returns the variance.

    betaprime.cdf: Function
        Evaluates the cumulative distribution function (CDF).

    betaprime.logcdf: Function
        Evaluates the natural logarithm of the cumulative distribution function
        (CDF).

    betaprime.logpdf: Function
        Evaluates the natural logarithm of the probability density function
        (PDF).

    betaprime.pdf: Function
        Evaluates the probability density function (PDF).

    betaprime.quantile: Function
        Evaluates the quantile function at probability `p`.

    Examples
    --------
    > var betaprime = base.dists.betaprime.BetaPrime( 6.0, 5.0 );
    > betaprime.alpha
    6.0
    > betaprime.beta
    5.0
    > betaprime.kurtosis
    44.4
    > betaprime.mean
    1.5
    > betaprime.mode
    ~0.833
    > betaprime.skewness
    ~3.578
    > betaprime.stdev
    ~1.118
    > betaprime.variance
    1.25
    > betaprime.cdf( 0.8 )
    ~0.25
    > betaprime.logcdf( 0.8 )
    ~-1.387
    > betaprime.logpdf( 1.0 )
    ~-0.486
    > betaprime.pdf( 1.0 )
    ~0.615
    > betaprime.quantile( 0.8 )
    ~2.06

        First shape parameter.

    β: number
        Second shape parameter.

    Returns
    -------

        Evaluated quantile function.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.betaprime.quantile( 0.8, 2.0, 1.0 )
    ~8.472
    > y = base.dists.betaprime.quantile( 0.5, 4.0, 2.0 )
    ~2.187
    > y = base.dists.betaprime.quantile( 1.1, 1.0, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.betaprime.quantile( -0.2, 1.0, 1.0 )
    NaN

    > y = base.dists.betaprime.quantile( NaN, 1.0, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.betaprime.quantile( 0.5, NaN, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.betaprime.quantile( 0.5, 1.0, NaN )
    NaN

    > y = base.dists.betaprime.quantile( 0.5, -1.0, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.betaprime.quantile( 0.5, 1.0, -1.0 )
    NaN

base.dists.binomial.Binomial:
base.dists.binomial.Binomial( [n, p] )
    Returns a binomial distribution object.

    Parameters
    ----------
    n: integer (optional)
        Number of trials. Must be a positive integer. Default: `1`.

    p: number (optional)
        Success probability. Must be a number between `0` and `1`. Default:
        `0.5`.

    Returns
    -------
    binomial: Object
        Distribution instance.

    binomial.n: number
        Number of trials. If set, the value must be a positive integer.

    binomial.p: number
        Success probability. If set, the value must be a number between `0` and
        `1`.

    binomial.kurtosis: number
        Read-only property which returns the excess kurtosis.

    binomial.mean: number
        Read-only property which returns the expected value.

    binomial.median: number
        Read-only property which returns the median.

    binomial.mode: number
        Read-only property which returns the mode.

    binomial.skewness: number
        Read-only property which returns the skewness.

    binomial.stdev: number
        Read-only property which returns the standard deviation.

    binomial.variance: number
        Read-only property which returns the variance.

    binomial.cdf: Function
        Evaluates the cumulative distribution function (CDF).

    binomial.logpmf: Function
        Evaluates the natural logarithm of the probability mass function (PMF).

    binomial.mgf: Function
        Evaluates the moment-generating function (MGF).

    binomial.pmf: Function
        Evaluates the probability mass function (PMF).

    binomial.quantile: Function
        Evaluates the quantile function at probability `p`.

    Examples
    --------
    > var binomial = base.dists.binomial.Binomial( 8, 0.5 );
    > binomial.n
    8.0
    > binomial.p
    0.5
    > binomial.kurtosis
    -0.25
    > binomial.mean
    4.0
    > binomial.median
    4.0
    > binomial.mode
    4.0
    > binomial.skewness
    0.0
    > binomial.stdev
    ~1.414
    > binomial.variance
    2.0
    > binomial.cdf( 2.9 )
    ~0.145
    > binomial.logpmf( 3.0 )
    ~-1.52
    > binomial.mgf( 0.2 )
    ~2.316
    > binomial.pmf( 3.0 )
    ~0.219
    > binomial.quantile( 0.8 )
    5.0
base.dists.binomial.cdf:
base.dists.binomial.cdf( x, n, p )
    Evaluates the cumulative distribution function (CDF) for a binomial
    distribution with number of trials `n` and success probability `p` at a
    value `x`.

    If provided `NaN` as any argument, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided a number of trials `n` which is not a nonnegative integer, the
    function returns `NaN`.

    If `p < 0` or `p > 1`, the function returns `NaN`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    x: number
        Input value.

    n: integer
        Number of trials.

    p: number
        Success probability.

    Returns
    -------
    out: number
        Evaluated CDF.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.binomial.cdf( 3.0, 20, 0.2 )
    ~0.411
    > y = base.dists.binomial.cdf( 21.0, 20, 0.2 )
    1.0
    > y = base.dists.binomial.cdf( 5.0, 10, 0.4 )
    ~0.834
    > y = base.dists.binomial.cdf( 0.0, 10, 0.4 )
    ~0.006
    > y = base.dists.binomial.cdf( NaN, 20, 0.5 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.binomial.cdf( 0.0, NaN, 0.5 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.binomial.cdf( 0.0, 20, NaN )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.binomial.cdf( 2.0, 1.5, 0.5 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.binomial.cdf( 2.0, -2.0, 0.5 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.binomial.cdf( 2.0, 20, -1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.binomial.cdf( 2.0, 20, 1.5 )
    NaN


base.dists.binomial.cdf.factory( n, p )
    Returns a function for evaluating the cumulative distribution function (CDF)
    of a binomial distribution with number of trials `n` and success probability
    `p`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    n: integer
        Number of trials.

    p: number
        Success probability.

    Returns
    -------
    cdf: Function
        Cumulative distribution function (CDF).

    Examples
    --------
    > var mycdf = base.dists.binomial.cdf.factory( 10, 0.5 );
    > var y = mycdf( 3.0 )
    ~0.172
    > y = mycdf( 1.0 )
    ~0.011

base.dists.binomial.quantile:
base.dists.binomial.quantile( r, n, p )
    Evaluates the quantile function for a binomial distribution with number of
    trials `n` and success probability `p` at a probability `r`.

    If `r < 0` or `r > 1`, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided a number of trials `n` which is not a nonnegative integer, the
    function returns `NaN`.

    If `p < 0` or `p > 1`, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided `NaN` as any argument, the function returns `NaN`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    r: number
        Input probability.

    n: integer
        Number of trials.

    p: number
        Success probability.

    Returns
    -------
    out: number
        Evaluated quantile function.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.binomial.quantile( 0.4, 20, 0.2 )
    3
    > y = base.dists.binomial.quantile( 0.8, 20, 0.2 )
    5
    > y = base.dists.binomial.quantile( 0.5, 10, 0.4 )
    4
    > y = base.dists.binomial.quantile( 0.0, 10, 0.4 )
    0
    > y = base.dists.binomial.quantile( 1.0, 10, 0.4 )
    10

    > y = base.dists.binomial.quantile( NaN, 20, 0.5 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.binomial.quantile( 0.2, NaN, 0.5 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.binomial.quantile( 0.2, 20, NaN )
    NaN

    > y = base.dists.binomial.quantile( 0.5, 1.5, 0.5 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.binomial.quantile( 0.5, -2.0, 0.5 )
    NaN

    > y = base.dists.binomial.quantile( 0.5, 20, -1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.binomial.quantile( 0.5, 20, 1.5 )
    NaN

base.dists.cauchy.Cauchy:
base.dists.cauchy.Cauchy( [x0, Ɣ] )
    Returns a Cauchy distribution object.

    Parameters
    ----------
    x0: number (optional)
        Location parameter. Default: `0.0`.

    Ɣ: number (optional)
        Scale parameter. Must be greater than `0`. Default: `1.0`.

    Returns
    -------
    cauchy: Object
        Distribution instance.

    cauchy.x0: number
        Location parameter.

    cauchy.gamma: number
        Scale parameter. If set, the value must be greater than `0`.

    cauchy.entropy: number
        Read-only property which returns the differential entropy.

    cauchy.median: number
        Read-only property which returns the median.

    cauchy.mode: number
        Read-only property which returns the mode.

    cauchy.cdf: Function
        Evaluates the cumulative distribution function (CDF).

    cauchy.logcdf: Function
        Evaluates the natural logarithm of the cumulative distribution function
        (CDF).

    cauchy.logpdf: Function
        Evaluates the natural logarithm of the probability density function
        (PDF).

    cauchy.pdf: Function
        Evaluates the probability density function (PDF).

    cauchy.quantile: Function
        Evaluates the quantile function at probability `p`.

    Examples
    --------
    > var cauchy = base.dists.cauchy.Cauchy( 0.0, 1.0 );
    > cauchy.x0
    0.0
    > cauchy.gamma
    1.0
    > cauchy.entropy
    ~2.531
    > cauchy.median
    0.0
    > cauchy.mode
    0.0
    > cauchy.cdf( 0.8 )
    ~0.715
    > cauchy.logcdf( 1.0 )
    ~-0.288
    > cauchy.logpdf( 1.0 )
    ~-1.838
    > cauchy.pdf( 1.0 )
    ~0.159
    > cauchy.quantile( 0.8 )
    ~1.376
base.dists.cauchy.cdf:
base.dists.cauchy.cdf( x, x0, Ɣ )
    Evaluates the cumulative distribution function (CDF) for a Cauchy
    distribution with location parameter `x0` and scale parameter `Ɣ` at a value
    `x`.

    If provided `NaN` as any argument, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided `Ɣ <= 0`, the function returns `NaN`.

    Parameters
    ----------

        Input value.

    x0: number
        Location parameter.

    Ɣ: number
        Scale parameter.

    Returns

        Evaluated CDF.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.cauchy.cdf( 4.0, 0.0, 2.0 )
    ~0.852
    > y = base.dists.cauchy.cdf( 1.0, 0.0, 2.0 )
    ~0.648
    > y = base.dists.cauchy.cdf( 1.0, 3.0, 2.0 )
    0.25
    > y = base.dists.cauchy.cdf( NaN, 0.0, 2.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.cauchy.cdf( 1.0, 2.0, NaN )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.cauchy.cdf( 1.0, NaN, 3.0 )
    NaN

    for a Cauchy distribution with location parameter `x0` and scale parameter
    `Ɣ` at a value `x`.

    ~-3.457
    > y = base.dists.cauchy.logpdf( 4.0, 3.0, 3.0 )

base.dists.cauchy.quantile:
base.dists.cauchy.quantile( p, x0, Ɣ )
    Evaluates the quantile function for a Cauchy distribution with location
    parameter `x0`  and scale parameter `Ɣ` at a probability `p`.

    If `p < 0` or `p > 1`, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided `NaN` as any argument, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided `Ɣ <= 0`, the function returns `NaN`.

        Input probability.

    x0: number
        Location parameter.

    Ɣ: number
        Scale parameter.

    Returns
    -------
    out: number
        Evaluated quantile function.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.cauchy.quantile( 0.3, 2.0, 2.0 )
    ~0.547
    > y = base.dists.cauchy.quantile( 0.8, 10, 2.0 )
    ~12.753
    > y = base.dists.cauchy.quantile( 0.1, 10.0, 2.0 )
    ~3.845

    > y = base.dists.cauchy.quantile( 1.1, 0.0, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.cauchy.quantile( -0.2, 0.0, 1.0 )
    NaN

    > y = base.dists.cauchy.quantile( NaN, 0.0, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.cauchy.quantile( 0.0, NaN, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.cauchy.quantile( 0.0, 0.0, NaN )
    NaN

    // Negative scale parameter:
    > y = base.dists.cauchy.quantile( 0.5, 0.0, -1.0 )
    NaN

base.dists.chi.cdf:
base.dists.chi.cdf( x, k )
    Evaluates the cumulative distribution function (CDF) for a chi distribution
    with degrees of freedom `k` at a value `x`.

    If provided `NaN` as any argument, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided `k < 0`, the function returns `NaN`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    x: number
        Input value.

    k: number
        Degrees of freedom.

    Returns
    -------
    out: number
        Evaluated CDF.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.chi.cdf( 2.0, 3.0 )
    ~0.739
    > y = base.dists.chi.cdf( 1.0, 0.5 )
    ~0.846
    > y = base.dists.chi.cdf( -1.0, 4.0 )
    0.0
    > y = base.dists.chi.cdf( NaN, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.chi.cdf( 0.0, NaN )
    NaN

    // Negative degrees of freedom:
    > y = base.dists.chi.cdf( 2.0, -1.0 )
    NaN

    // Degenerate distribution when `k = 0`:
    > y = base.dists.chi.cdf( 2.0, 0.0 )
    1.0
    > y = base.dists.chi.cdf( -2.0, 0.0 )
    0.0
    > y = base.dists.chi.cdf( 0.0, 0.0 )
    0.0

base.dists.chi.cdf.factory( k )
    Returns a function for evaluating the cumulative distribution function (CDF)
    of a chi distribution with degrees of freedom `k`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    k: number
        Degrees of freedom.

    Returns
    -------
    cdf: Function
        Cumulative distribution function (CDF).

    Examples
    --------
    > var mycdf = base.dists.chi.cdf.factory( 1.0 );
    > var y = mycdf( 2.0 )
    ~0.954
    > y = mycdf( 1.2 )
    ~0.77

base.dists.chi.Chi:
base.dists.chi.Chi( [k] )
    Returns a chi distribution object.

    Parameters
    ----------
    k: number (optional)
        Degrees of freedom. Must be greater than `0`. Default: `1.0`.

    Returns
    -------
    chi: Object
        Distribution instance.

    chi.k: number
        Degrees of freedom. If set, the value must be greater than `0`.

    chi.entropy: number
        Read-only property which returns the differential entropy.

    chi.kurtosis: number
        Read-only property which returns the excess kurtosis.

    chi.mean: number
        Read-only property which returns the expected value.

    chi.mode: number
        Read-only property which returns the mode.

    chi.skewness: number
        Read-only property which returns the skewness.

    chi.stdev: number
        Read-only property which returns the standard deviation.

    chi.variance: number
        Read-only property which returns the variance.

    chi.cdf: Function
        Evaluates the cumulative distribution function (CDF).

    chi.logpdf: Function
        Evaluates the natural logarithm of the probability density function
        (PDF).

    chi.pdf: Function
        Evaluates the probability density function (PDF).

    chi.quantile: Function
        Evaluates the quantile function at probability `p`.

    Examples
    --------
    > var chi = base.dists.chi.Chi( 6.0 );
    > chi.k
    6.0
    > chi.entropy
    ~1.04
    > chi.kurtosis
    ~0.025
    > chi.mean
    ~2.35
    > chi.mode
    ~2.236
    > chi.skewness
    ~0.318
    > chi.stdev
    ~0.691
    > chi.variance
    ~0.478
    > chi.cdf( 1.0 )
    ~0.014
    > chi.logpdf( 1.5 )
    ~-1.177
    > chi.pdf( 1.5 )
    ~0.308
    > chi.quantile( 0.5 )
    ~2.313

base.dists.chi.logpdf:
base.dists.chi.logpdf( x, k )
    Evaluates the natural logarithm of the probability density function (PDF)
    for a chi distribution with degrees of freedom `k` at a value `x`.

    If provided `NaN` as any argument, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided `k < 0`, the function returns `NaN`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    x: number
        Input value.

    k: number
        Degrees of freedom.

    Returns
    -------
    out: number
        Evaluated logPDF.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.chi.logpdf( 0.3, 4.0 )
    ~-4.35
    > y = base.dists.chi.logpdf( 0.7, 0.7 )
    ~-0.622
    > y = base.dists.chi.logpdf( -1.0, 0.5 )
    -Infinity
    > y = base.dists.chi.logpdf( 0.0, NaN )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.chi.logpdf( NaN, 2.0 )
    NaN

    // Negative degrees of freedom:
    > y = base.dists.chi.logpdf( 2.0, -1.0 )
    NaN

    // Degenerate distribution when `k = 0`:
    > y = base.dists.chi.logpdf( 2.0, 0.0, 2.0 )
    -Infinity
    > y = base.dists.chi.logpdf( 0.0, 0.0, 2.0 )
    Infinity

    > y = base.dists.chisquare.cdf( -2.0, 0.0 )
    0.0
    > y = base.dists.chisquare.cdf( 0.0, 0.0 )
    0.0

base.dists.chisquare.ChiSquare:
base.dists.chisquare.ChiSquare( [k] )
    Returns a  chi-squared distribution object.

    Parameters
    ----------
    k: number (optional)
        Degrees of freedom. Must be greater than `0`. Default: `1.0`.

    Returns
    -------
    chisquare: Object
        Distribution instance.

    chisquare.k: number
        Degrees of freedom. If set, the value must be greater than `0`.

    chisquare.entropy: number
        Read-only property which returns the differential entropy.

    chisquare.kurtosis: number
        Read-only property which returns the excess kurtosis.

    chisquare.mean: number
        Read-only property which returns the expected value.

    chisquare.mgf: Function
        Evaluates the moment-generating function (MGF).

    chisquare.mode: number
        Read-only property which returns the mode.

    chisquare.skewness: number
        Read-only property which returns the skewness.

    chisquare.stdev: number
        Read-only property which returns the standard deviation.

    chisquare.variance: number
        Read-only property which returns the variance.

    chisquare.cdf: Function
        Evaluates the cumulative distribution function (CDF).

    chisquare.pdf: Function
        Evaluates the probability density function (PDF).

    chisquare.quantile: Function
        Evaluates the quantile function at probability `p`.

    Examples
    --------
    > var chisquare = base.dists.chisquare.ChiSquare( 6.0 );
    > chisquare.k
    6.0
    > chisquare.entropy
    ~2.541
    > chisquare.kurtosis
    2.0
    > chisquare.mean
    6.0
    > chisquare.mode
    4.0
    > chisquare.skewness
    ~1.155
    > chisquare.stdev
    ~3.464
    > chisquare.variance
    12.0
    > chisquare.cdf( 3.0 )
    ~0.191
    > chisquare.mgf( 0.2 )
    ~4.63
    > chisquare.pdf( 1.5 )
    ~0.066
    > chisquare.quantile( 0.5 )
    ~5.348
base.dists.chisquare.entropy:

    If provided `k < 0`, the function returns `NaN`.

    out: number

    Examples

    ~2.901
    > v = base.dists.chisquare.entropy( 1.5 )
    ~1.375

    If provided `k <= 0`, the function returns `NaN`.

    > v = base.dists.chisquare.kurtosis( 1.5 )

base.dists.chisquare.logpdf:
base.dists.chisquare.logpdf( x, k )
    Evaluates the natural logarithm of the probability density function (PDF)
    for a chi-squared distribution with degrees of freedom `k` at a value `x`.

    If provided `NaN` as any argument, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided `k < 0`, the function returns `NaN`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    x: number
        Input value.

    k: number
        Degrees of freedom.

    Returns
    -------
    out: number
        Evaluated logPDF.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.chisquare.logpdf( 0.3, 4.0 )
    ~-2.74
    > y = base.dists.chisquare.logpdf( 0.7, 0.7 )
    ~-1.295
    > y = base.dists.chisquare.logpdf( -1.0, 0.5 )
    -Infinity
    > y = base.dists.chisquare.logpdf( 0.0, NaN )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.chisquare.logpdf( NaN, 2.0 )
    NaN

    // Negative degrees of freedom:
    > y = base.dists.chisquare.logpdf( 2.0, -1.0 )
    NaN

    // Degenerate distribution when `k = 0`:
    > y = base.dists.chisquare.logpdf( 2.0, 0.0, 2.0 )
    -Infinity
    > y = base.dists.chisquare.logpdf( 0.0, 0.0, 2.0 )
    Infinity


base.dists.chisquare.logpdf.factory( k )
    Returns a function for evaluating the natural logarithm of the probability
    density function (PDF) of a chi-squared distribution with degrees of freedom
    `k`.

    Parameters

        Degrees of freedom.

    Returns

    logpdf: Function

    Examples

    > var y = myLogPDF( 3.0 )
    ~-2.075

base.dists.chisquare.quantile:
base.dists.chisquare.quantile( p, k )
    Evaluates the quantile function for a chi-squared distribution with degrees
    of freedom `k` at a probability `p`.

    If `p < 0` or `p > 1`, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided `NaN` for any argument, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided `k < 0`, the function returns `NaN`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    p: number
        Input probability.

    k: number
        Degrees of freedom.

    Returns
    -------
    out: number
        Evaluated quantile function.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.chisquare.quantile( 0.8, 1.0 )
    ~1.642
    > y = base.dists.chisquare.quantile( 0.5, 4.0 )
    ~3.357
    > y = base.dists.chisquare.quantile( 0.8, 0.1 )
    ~0.014
    > y = base.dists.chisquare.quantile( -0.2, 0.5 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.chisquare.quantile( 1.1, 0.5 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.chisquare.quantile( NaN, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.chisquare.quantile( 0.0, NaN )
    NaN

    // Negative degrees of freedom:
    > y = base.dists.chisquare.quantile( 0.5, -1.0 )
    NaN

    // Degenerate distribution when `k = 0`:
    > y = base.dists.chisquare.quantile( 0.3, 0.0 )
    0.0
    > y = base.dists.chisquare.quantile( 0.9, 0.0 )
    0.0


base.dists.chisquare.quantile.factory( k )
    Returns a function for evaluating the quantile function of a chi-squared
    distribution with degrees of freedom `k`.

    > var y = myquantile( 0.3 )
    ~0.713
    > y = myquantile( 0.7 )
    ~2.408

base.dists.cosine.cdf:
base.dists.cosine.cdf( x, μ, s )
    Evaluates the cumulative distribution function (CDF) for a raised cosine
    distribution with location parameter `μ` and scale parameter `s` at a value
    `x`.

    If provided `NaN` as any argument, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided `s < 0`, the function returns `NaN`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    x: number
        Input value.

    μ: number
        Location parameter.

    s: number
        Scale parameter.

    Returns
    -------
    out: number
        Evaluated CDF.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.cosine.cdf( 2.0, 0.0, 3.0 )
    ~0.971
    > y = base.dists.cosine.cdf( 9.0, 10.0, 3.0 )
    ~0.196

    > y = base.dists.cosine.cdf( 2.0, 0.0, NaN )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.cosine.cdf( 2.0, NaN, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.cosine.cdf( NaN, 0.0, 1.0 )
    NaN

    // Degenerate distribution centered at `μ` when `s = 0.0`:
    > y = base.dists.cosine.cdf( 2.0, 8.0, 0.0 )
    0.0
    > y = base.dists.cosine.cdf( 8.0, 8.0, 0.0 )
    1.0
    > y = base.dists.cosine.cdf( 10.0, 8.0, 0.0 )
    1.0

        Distribution instance.

    cosine.mu: number
        Location parameter.

    cosine.s: number
        Scale parameter. If set, the value must be greater than `0`.

        Read-only property which returns the excess kurtosis.

    cosine.mean: number
        Read-only property which returns the expected value.

    cosine.median: number
        Read-only property which returns the median.

    cosine.mode: number
        Read-only property which returns the mode.

    cosine.skewness: number
        Read-only property which returns the skewness.

        (CDF).

        (PDF).

        Evaluates the moment-generating function (MGF).

    cosine.pdf: Function
        Evaluates the probability density function (PDF).

    cosine.quantile: Function

    Examples
    --------

    -2.0

    0.0

    ~1.085
    > cosine.variance
    ~1.176

    ~0.996
    > cosine.logcdf( 0.5 )

base.dists.cosine.logpdf:
base.dists.cosine.logpdf( x, μ, s )
    Evaluates the logarithm of the probability density function (PDF) for a
    raised cosine distribution with location parameter `μ` and scale parameter
    `s` at a value `x`.

    If provided `NaN` as any argument, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided `s < 0`, the function returns `NaN`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    x: number
        Input value.

    μ: number
        Location parameter.

    s: number
        Scale parameter.

    Returns
    -------
    out: number
        Evaluated logPDF.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.cosine.logpdf( 2.0, 0.0, 3.0 )
    ~-2.485
    > y = base.dists.cosine.logpdf( -1.0, 2.0, 4.0 )
    ~-3.307
    > y = base.dists.cosine.logpdf( NaN, 0.0, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.cosine.logpdf( 0.0, NaN, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.cosine.logpdf( 0.0, 0.0, NaN )
    NaN

    // Negative scale parameter:
    > y = base.dists.cosine.logpdf( 2.0, 0.0, -1.0 )
    NaN

    // Degenerate distribution at `s = 0.0`:
    > y = base.dists.cosine.logpdf( 2.0, 8.0, 0.0 )
    -Infinity
    > y = base.dists.cosine.logpdf( 8.0, 8.0, 0.0 )
    Infinity

base.dists.cosine.quantile:
base.dists.cosine.quantile( p, μ, s )
    Evaluates the quantile function for a raised cosine distribution with
    location parameter `μ` and scale parameter `s` at a probability `p`.

    If `p < 0` or `p > 1`, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided `NaN` as any argument, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided `s < 0`, the function returns `NaN`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    p: number
        Input probability.

    μ: number
        Location parameter.

    s: number
        Scale parameter.

    Returns
    -------
    out: number
        Evaluated quantile function.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.cosine.quantile( 0.8, 0.0, 1.0 )
    ~0.327
    > y = base.dists.cosine.quantile( 0.5, 4.0, 2.0 )
    ~4.0

    > y = base.dists.cosine.quantile( 1.1, 0.0, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.cosine.quantile( -0.2, 0.0, 1.0 )
    NaN

    > y = base.dists.cosine.quantile( NaN, 0.0, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.cosine.quantile( 0.0, NaN, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.cosine.quantile( 0.0, 0.0, NaN )
    NaN

    // Negative scale parameter:
    > y = base.dists.cosine.quantile( 0.5, 0.0, -1.0 )
    NaN

base.dists.degenerate.Degenerate:
base.dists.degenerate.Degenerate( [μ] )
    Returns a degenerate distribution object.

    Parameters
    ----------
    μ: number (optional)
        Constant value of distribution.

    Returns
    -------
    degenerate: Object
        Distribution instance.

    degenerate.mu: number
        Constant value of distribution.

    degenerate.entropy: number
        Read-only property which returns the differential entropy.

    degenerate.mean: number
        Read-only property which returns the expected value.

    degenerate.median: number
        Read-only property which returns the median.

    degenerate.stdev: number
        Read-only property which returns the standard deviation.

    degenerate.variance: number
        Read-only property which returns the variance.

    degenerate.cdf: Function
        Evaluates the cumulative distribution function (CDF).

    degenerate.logcdf: Function
        Evaluates the natural logarithm of the cumulative distribution function
        (CDF).

    degenerate.logpdf: Function
        Evaluates the natural logarithm of the probability density function
        (PDF).

    degenerate.logpmf: Function
        Evaluates the natural logarithm of the probability mass function
        (PMF).

    degenerate.mgf: Function
        Evaluates the moment-generating function (MGF).

    degenerate.pmf: Function
        Evaluates the probability mass function (PMF).

    degenerate.pdf: Function
        Evaluates the probability density function (PDF).

    degenerate.quantile: Function
        Evaluates the quantile function at probability `p`.

    Examples
    --------
    > var degenerate = base.dists.degenerate.Degenerate( 2.0 );
    > degenerate.mu
    2.0
    > degenerate.entropy
    0.0
    > degenerate.mean
    2.0
    > degenerate.mode
    2.0
    > degenerate.median
    2.0
    > degenerate.stdev
    0.0
    > degenerate.variance
    0.0
    > degenerate.cdf( 0.5 )
    0.0
    > degenerate.logcdf( 2.5 )
    0.0
    > degenerate.logpdf( 0.5 )
    -Infinity
    > degenerate.logpmf( 2.5 )
    -Infinity
    > degenerate.mgf( 0.2 )
    ~1.492
    > degenerate.pdf( 2.0 )
    +Infinity
    > degenerate.pmf( 2.0 )
    1.0
    > degenerate.quantile( 0.7 )
    2.0

base.dists.discreteUniform.cdf:
base.dists.discreteUniform.cdf( x, a, b )
    Evaluates the cumulative distribution function (CDF) for a discrete uniform
    distribution with minimum support `a` and maximum support `b` at a value
    `x`.

    If `a > b`, the function returns `NaN`.

    If `a` or `b` is not an integer value, the function returns `NaN`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    x: number
        Input value.

    a: integer
        Minimum support.

    b: integer
        Maximum support.

    Returns
    -------
    out: number
        Evaluated CDF.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.discreteUniform.cdf( 9.0, 0, 10 )
    ~0.909
    > y = base.dists.discreteUniform.cdf( 0.5, 0, 2 )
    ~0.333
    > y = base.dists.discreteUniform.cdf( PINF, 2, 4 )
    1.0
    > y = base.dists.discreteUniform.cdf( NINF, 2, 4 )
    0.0
    > y = base.dists.discreteUniform.cdf( NaN, 0, 1 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.discreteUniform.cdf( 0.0, NaN, 1 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.discreteUniform.cdf( 0.0, 0, NaN )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.discreteUniform.cdf( 2.0, 1, 0 )
    NaN


base.dists.discreteUniform.cdf.factory( a, b )
    Returns a function for evaluating the cumulative distribution function (CDF)
    of a discrete uniform distribution with minimum support `a` and maximum
    support `b`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    a: integer
        Minimum support.

    b: integer
        Maximum support.

    Returns
    -------
    cdf: Function
        Cumulative distribution function (CDF).

    Examples
    --------
    > var mycdf = base.dists.discreteUniform.cdf.factory( 0, 10 );
    > var y = mycdf( 0.5 )
    ~0.091
    > y = mycdf( 8.0 )
    ~0.818

base.dists.discreteUniform.DiscreteUnifo:
base.dists.discreteUniform.DiscreteUniform( [a, b] )
    Returns a discrete uniform distribution object.

    Parameters
    ----------
    a: integer (optional)
        Minimum support. Must be an integer smaller than `b`. Default: `0`.

    b: integer (optional)
        Maximum support. Must be an integer greater than `a`. Default: `1`.

    Returns
    -------
    discreteUniform: Object
        Distribution instance.

    discreteUniform.a: integer
        Minimum support. If set, the value must be an integer smaller than or
        equal to `b`.

    discreteUniform.b: integer
        Maximum support. If set, the value must be an integer greater than or
        equal to `a`.

    discreteUniform.entropy: number
        Read-only property which returns the entropy.

    discreteUniform.kurtosis: number
        Read-only property which returns the excess kurtosis.

    discreteUniform.mean: number
        Read-only property which returns the expected value.

    discreteUniform.median: number
        Read-only property which returns the median.

    discreteUniform.skewness: number
        Read-only property which returns the skewness.

    discreteUniform.stdev: number
        Read-only property which returns the standard deviation.

    discreteUniform.variance: number
        Read-only property which returns the variance.

    discreteUniform.cdf: Function
        Evaluates the cumulative distribution function (CDF).

    discreteUniform.logcdf: Function
        Evaluates the natural logarithm of the cumulative distribution function
        (CDF).

    discreteUniform.logpmf: Function
        Evaluates the natural logarithm of the probability mass function (PMF).

    discreteUniform.mgf: Function
        Evaluates the moment-generating function (MGF).

    discreteUniform.pmf: Function
        Evaluates the probability mass function (PMF).

    discreteUniform.quantile: Function
        Evaluates the quantile function at probability `p`.

    Examples
    --------
    > var discreteUniform = base.dists.discreteUniform.DiscreteUniform( -2, 2 );
    > discreteUniform.a
    -2
    > discreteUniform.b
    2
    > discreteUniform.entropy
    ~1.609
    > discreteUniform.kurtosis
    -1.3
    > discreteUniform.mean
    0.0
    > discreteUniform.median
    0.0
    > discreteUniform.skewness
    0.0
    > discreteUniform.stdev
    ~1.414
    > discreteUniform.variance
    2.0
    > discreteUniform.cdf( 0.8 )
    0.6
    > discreteUniform.logcdf( 0.5 )
    ~-0.511
    > discreteUniform.logpmf( 1.0 )
    ~-1.609
    > discreteUniform.mgf( 0.8 )
    ~1.766
    > discreteUniform.pmf( 0.0 )
    0.2
    > discreteUniform.quantile( 0.8 )
    2.0

base.dists.discreteUniform.pmf:
base.dists.discreteUniform.pmf( x, a, b )
    Evaluates the probability mass function (PMF) for a discrete uniform
    distribution with minimum support `a` and maximum support `b` at a value
    `x`.

    If `a > b`, the function returns `NaN`.

    If `a` or `b` is not an integer value, the function returns `NaN`.

    Parameters
    ----------

        Input value.

    a: integer
        Minimum support.

    b: integer
        Maximum support.

    Returns
    -------
    out: number
        Evaluated PMF.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.discreteUniform.pmf( 2.0, 0, 4 )
    ~0.2
    > y = base.dists.discreteUniform.pmf( 5.0, 0, 4 )
    0.0
    > y = base.dists.discreteUniform.pmf( 3.0, -4, 4 )
    ~0.111
    > y = base.dists.discreteUniform.pmf( NaN, 0, 1 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.discreteUniform.pmf( 0.0, NaN, 1 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.discreteUniform.pmf( 0.0, 0, NaN )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.discreteUniform.pmf( 2.0, 3, 1 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.discreteUniform.pmf( 2.0, 1, 2.4 )
    NaN

base.dists.discreteUniform.quantile:
base.dists.discreteUniform.quantile( p, a, b )
    Evaluates the quantile function for a discrete uniform distribution with
    minimum support `a` and maximum support `b` at a probability `p`.

    If `p < 0` or `p > 1`, the function returns `NaN`.

    If `a` or `b` is not an integer value, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided `a > b`, the function returns `NaN`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    p: number
        Input probability.

    a: integer
        Minimum support.

    b: integer
        Maximum support.

    Returns
    -------
    out: number
        Evaluated quantile function.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.discreteUniform.quantile( 0.8, 0, 1 )
    1
    > y = base.dists.discreteUniform.quantile( 0.5, 0.0, 10.0 )
    5

    > y = base.dists.discreteUniform.quantile( 1.1, 0, 4 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.discreteUniform.quantile( -0.2, 0, 4 )
    NaN

    > y = base.dists.discreteUniform.quantile( NaN, -2, 2 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.discreteUniform.quantile( 0.1, NaN, 2 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.discreteUniform.quantile( 0.1, -2, NaN )
    NaN

    > y = base.dists.discreteUniform.quantile( 0.5, 2, 1 )
    NaN


base.dists.discreteUniform.quantile.factory( a, b )

base.dists.erlang.cdf:
base.dists.erlang.cdf( x, k, λ )
    Evaluates the cumulative distribution function (CDF) for an Erlang
    distribution with shape parameter `k` and rate parameter `λ` at a value
    `x`.

    If provided `NaN` as any argument, the function returns `NaN`.

    If not provided a nonnegative integer for `k`, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided a non-positive value for `λ`, the function returns `NaN`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    x: number
        Input value.

    k: number
        Shape parameter.

    λ: number
        Rate parameter.

    Returns
    -------
    out: number
        Evaluated CDF.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.erlang.cdf( 2.0, 1, 1.0 )
    ~0.865
    > y = base.dists.erlang.cdf( 2.0, 3, 1.0 )
    ~0.323
    > y = base.dists.erlang.cdf( 2.0, 2.5, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.erlang.cdf( -1.0, 2, 2.0 )
    0.0
    > y = base.dists.erlang.cdf( PINF, 4, 2.0 )
    1.0
    > y = base.dists.erlang.cdf( NINF, 4, 2.0 )
    0.0
    > y = base.dists.erlang.cdf( NaN, 0, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.erlang.cdf( 0.0, NaN, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.erlang.cdf( 0.0, 0, NaN )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.erlang.cdf( 2.0, -1, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.erlang.cdf( 2.0, 1, -1.0 )
    NaN


base.dists.erlang.cdf.factory( k, λ )

    ~0.264

base.dists.erlang.Erlang:
base.dists.erlang.Erlang( [k, λ] )
    Returns an Erlang distribution object.

    Parameters
    ----------
    k: number (optional)
        Shape parameter. Must be a positive integer. Default: `1.0`.

    λ: number (optional)
        Rate parameter. Must be greater than `0`. Default: `1.0`.

    Returns
    -------
    erlang: Object
        Distribution instance.

    erlang.k: number
        Shape parameter. If set, the value must be a positive integer.

    erlang.lambda: number
        Rate parameter. If set, the value must be greater than `0`.

    erlang.entropy: number
        Read-only property which returns the differential entropy.

    erlang.kurtosis: number
        Read-only property which returns the excess kurtosis.

    erlang.mean: number
        Read-only property which returns the expected value.

    erlang.mode: number
        Read-only property which returns the mode.

    erlang.skewness: number
        Read-only property which returns the skewness.

    erlang.stdev: number
        Read-only property which returns the standard deviation.

    erlang.variance: number
        Read-only property which returns the variance.

    erlang.cdf: Function
        Evaluates the cumulative distribution function (CDF).

    erlang.logpdf: Function
        Evaluates the natural logarithm of the probability density function
        (PDF).

    erlang.mgf: Function
        Evaluates the moment-generating function (MGF).

    erlang.pdf: Function
        Evaluates the probability density function (PDF).

    erlang.quantile: Function
        Evaluates the quantile function at probability `p`.

    Examples
    --------
    > var erlang = base.dists.erlang.Erlang( 6, 5.0 );
    > erlang.k
    6
    > erlang.lambda
    5.0
    > erlang.entropy
    ~0.647
    > erlang.kurtosis
    1.0
    > erlang.mean
    1.2
    > erlang.mode
    1.0
    > erlang.skewness
    ~0.816
    > erlang.stdev
    ~0.49
    > erlang.variance
    0.24
    > erlang.cdf( 3.0 )
    ~0.997
    > erlang.logpdf( 3.0 )
    ~-4.638
    > erlang.mgf( -0.5 )
    ~0.564
    > erlang.pdf( 3.0 )
    ~0.01
    > erlang.quantile( 0.8 )
    ~1.581

    at a value `x`.

    parameter `k` and rate parameter `λ` at a probability `p`.

    If `p < 0` or `p > 1`, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided `NaN` as any argument, the function returns `NaN`.

    If not provided a nonnegative integer for `k`, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided a non-positive number for `λ`, the function returns `NaN`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    p: number
        Input probability.

    k: number
        Shape parameter.

    λ: number
        Rate parameter.

    Returns
    -------
    out: number
        Evaluated quantile function.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.erlang.quantile( 0.8, 2, 1.0 )
    ~2.994
    > y = base.dists.erlang.quantile( 0.5, 4, 2.0 )
    ~1.836

    > y = base.dists.erlang.quantile( 1.1, 1, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.erlang.quantile( -0.2, 1, 1.0 )
    NaN

    > y = base.dists.erlang.quantile( NaN, 1, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.erlang.quantile( 0.0, NaN, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.erlang.quantile( 0.0, 1, NaN )
    NaN

    // Non-integer shape parameter:
    > y = base.dists.erlang.quantile( 0.5, 0.5, 1.0 )
    NaN
    // Non-positive shape parameter:
    > y = base.dists.erlang.quantile( 0.5, -1, 1.0 )
    NaN
    // Non-positive rate parameter:
    > y = base.dists.erlang.quantile( 0.5, 1, -1.0 )
    NaN

        Shape parameter.

        Rate parameter.

    Examples
    --------

    > var y = myQuantile( 0.4 )
    ~4.452

base.dists.exponential.Exponential:
base.dists.exponential.Exponential( [λ] )
    Returns an exponential distribution object.

    Parameters
    ----------
    λ: number (optional)
        Rate parameter. Must be greater than `0`. Default: `1.0`.

    Returns
    -------
    exponential: Object
        Distribution instance.

    exponential.lambda: number
        Rate parameter. If set, the value must be greater than `0`.

    exponential.entropy: number
        Read-only property which returns the differential entropy.

    exponential.kurtosis: number
        Read-only property which returns the excess kurtosis.

    exponential.mean: number
        Read-only property which returns the expected value.

    exponential.median: number
        Read-only property which returns the median.

    exponential.mode: number
        Read-only property which returns the mode.

    exponential.skewness: number
        Read-only property which returns the skewness.

    exponential.stdev: number
        Read-only property which returns the standard deviation.

    exponential.variance: number
        Read-only property which returns the variance.

    exponential.cdf: Function
        Evaluates the cumulative distribution function (CDF).

    exponential.logcdf: Function
        Evaluates the natural logarithm of the cumulative distribution function
        (CDF).

    exponential.logpdf: Function
        Evaluates the natural logarithm of the probability density function
        (PDF).

    exponential.mgf: Function
        Evaluates the moment-generating function (MGF).

    exponential.pdf: Function
        Evaluates the probability density function (PDF).

    exponential.quantile: Function
        Evaluates the quantile function at probability `p`.

    Examples
    --------
    > var exponential = base.dists.exponential.Exponential( 6.0 );
    > exponential.lambda
    6.0
    > exponential.entropy
    ~-0.792
    > exponential.kurtosis
    6.0
    > exponential.mean
    ~0.167
    > exponential.median
    ~0.116
    > exponential.mode
    0.0
    > exponential.skewness
    2.0
    > exponential.stdev
    ~0.167
    > exponential.variance
    ~0.028
    > exponential.cdf( 1.0 )
    ~0.998
    > exponential.logcdf( 1.0 )
    ~-0.002
    > exponential.logpdf( 1.5 )
    ~-7.208
    > exponential.mgf( -0.5 )
    ~0.923
    > exponential.pdf( 1.5 )
    ~0.001
    > exponential.quantile( 0.5 )
    ~0.116

base.dists.f.F:
base.dists.f.F( [d1, d2] )
    Returns an F distribution object.

    Parameters
    ----------
    d1: number (optional)
        Numerator degrees of freedom. Must be greater than `0`. Default: `1.0`.

        Default: `1.0`.

    -------
    f: Object

        `0`.

    f.d2: number
        Denominator degrees of freedom. If set, the value must be greater than
        `0`.

    f.entropy: number
        Read-only property which returns the differential entropy.

    f.kurtosis: number
        Read-only property which returns the excess kurtosis.

    f.mean: number
        Read-only property which returns the expected value.

    f.mode: number
        Read-only property which returns the mode.

    f.skewness: number
        Read-only property which returns the skewness.

    f.stdev: number
        Read-only property which returns the standard deviation.

    f.variance: number
        Read-only property which returns the variance.

    f.cdf: Function
        Evaluates the cumulative distribution function (CDF).

    f.pdf: Function
        Evaluates the probability density function (PDF).

    f.quantile: Function
        Evaluates the quantile function at probability `p`.

    Examples
    --------
    > var f = base.dists.f.F( 6.0, 9.0 );
    > f.d1
    6.0
    > f.d2
    9.0
    > f.entropy
    ~1.134
    > f.kurtosis
    ~104.564
    > f.mean
    ~1.286
    > f.mode
    ~0.545
    > f.skewness
    ~4.535
    > f.stdev
    ~1.197
    > f.variance
    ~1.433
    > f.cdf( 3.0 )
    ~0.932
    > f.pdf( 2.5 )
    ~0.095
    > f.quantile( 0.8 )
    ~1.826

base.dists.f.quantile:
base.dists.f.quantile( p, d1, d2 )
    Evaluates the quantile function for an F distribution with numerator degrees
    of freedom `d1` and denominator degrees of freedom `d2` at a probability
    `p`.

    If provided `NaN` as any argument, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided `d1 <= 0` or `d2 <= 0`, the function returns `NaN`.

    Parameters
    ----------

        Input probability.

    d1: number
        Numerator degrees of freedom.

    d2: number
        Denominator degrees of freedom.

    Returns
    -------
    out: number
        Evaluated quantile function.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.f.quantile( 0.8, 1.0, 1.0 )
    ~9.472
    > y = base.dists.f.quantile( 0.5, 4.0, 2.0 )
    ~1.207

    > y = base.dists.f.quantile( 1.1, 1.0, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.f.quantile( -0.2, 1.0, 1.0 )
    NaN

    > y = base.dists.f.quantile( NaN, 1.0, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.f.quantile( 0.5, NaN, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.f.quantile( 0.5, 1.0, NaN )
    NaN

    > y = base.dists.f.quantile( 0.5, -1.0, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.f.quantile( 0.5, 1.0, -1.0 )
    NaN

base.dists.frechet.Frechet:
base.dists.frechet.Frechet( [α, s, m] )
    Returns a Fréchet distribution object.

    Parameters
    ----------
    α: number (optional)
        Shape parameter. Must be greater than `0`. Default: `1.0`.

    s: number (optional)
        Scale parameter. Must be greater than `0`. Default: `1.0`.

    m: number (optional)
        Location parameter. Default: `0.0`.

    Returns
    -------
    frechet: Object
        Distribution instance.

    frechet.alpha: number
        Shape parameter. If set, the value must be greater than `0`.

    frechet.s: number
        Scale parameter. If set, the value must be greater than `0`.

    frechet.m: number
        Location parameter.

    frechet.entropy: number
        Read-only property which returns the differential entropy.

    frechet.kurtosis: number
        Read-only property which returns the excess kurtosis.

    frechet.mean: number
        Read-only property which returns the expected value.

    frechet.median: number
        Read-only property which returns the median.

    frechet.mode: number
        Read-only property which returns the mode.

    frechet.skewness: number
        Read-only property which returns the skewness.

    frechet.stdev: number
        Read-only property which returns the standard deviation.

    frechet.variance: number
        Read-only property which returns the variance.

    frechet.cdf: Function
        Evaluates the cumulative distribution function (CDF).

    frechet.logcdf: Function
        Evaluates the natural logarithm of the cumulative distribution function
        (CDF).

    frechet.logpdf: Function
        Evaluates the natural logarithm of the probability density function
        (PDF).

    frechet.pdf: Function
        Evaluates the probability density function (PDF).

    frechet.quantile: Function
        Evaluates the quantile function at probability `p`.

    Examples

    > frechet.s

    Infinity

    0.5

    Infinity

    Infinity

    Infinity

    ~0.448

    ~4.481

    Returns the excess kurtosis of a Fréchet distribution with shape parameter
    `α`, scale parameter `s`, and location `m`.

    If provided `0 < α <= 4` and `s > 0`, the function returns positive
    infinity.

    If provided `NaN` as any argument, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided `α <= 0` or `s <= 0`, the function returns `NaN`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    α: number
        Shape parameter.

    s: number
        Scale parameter.

    m: number
        Location parameter.

    Returns

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.frechet.kurtosis( 5.0, 2.0, 1.0 )
    ~45.092
    > var y = base.dists.frechet.kurtosis( 5.0, 10.0, -3.0 )
    ~45.092
    > y = base.dists.frechet.kurtosis( 3.5, 2.0, 1.0 )
    Infinity
    > y = base.dists.frechet.kurtosis( NaN, 1.0, 0.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.frechet.kurtosis( 1.0, NaN, 0.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.frechet.kurtosis( 1.0, 1.0, NaN )
    NaN

base.dists.gamma.cdf:
base.dists.gamma.cdf( x, α, β )
    Evaluates the cumulative distribution function (CDF) for a gamma
    distribution with shape parameter `α` and rate parameter `β` at a value `x`.

    If `α < 0` or `β <= 0`, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided `NaN` as any argument, the function returns `NaN`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    x: number
        Input value.

    α: number
        Shape parameter.

    β: number
        Rate parameter.

    Returns
    -------
    out: number
        Evaluated CDF.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.gamma.cdf( 2.0, 1.0, 1.0 )
    ~0.865
    > y = base.dists.gamma.cdf( 2.0, 3.0, 1.0 )
    ~0.323
    > y = base.dists.gamma.cdf( -1.0, 2.0, 2.0 )
    0.0
    > y = base.dists.gamma.cdf( PINF, 4.0, 2.0 )
    1.0
    > y = base.dists.gamma.cdf( NINF, 4.0, 2.0 )
    0.0

    > y = base.dists.gamma.cdf( NaN, 0.0, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.gamma.cdf( 0.0, NaN, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.gamma.cdf( 0.0, 0.0, NaN )
    NaN

    > y = base.dists.gamma.cdf( 2.0, -1.0, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.gamma.cdf( 2.0, 1.0, -1.0 )
    NaN

    // Degenerate distribution centered at `0` when `α = 0.0`:
    > y = base.dists.gamma.cdf( 2.0, 0.0, 2.0 )
    1.0
    > y = base.dists.gamma.cdf( -2.0, 0.0, 2.0 )
    0.0
    > y = base.dists.gamma.cdf( 0.0, 0.0, 2.0 )
    0.0


base.dists.gamma.cdf.factory( α, β )
    Returns a function for evaluating the cumulative distribution function (CDF)
    of a gamma distribution with shape parameter `α` and rate parameter `β`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    α: number
        Shape parameter.

    β: number
        Rate parameter.

    Returns
    -------
    cdf: Function
        Cumulative distribution function (CDF).

    Examples
    --------
    > var myCDF = base.dists.gamma.cdf.factory( 2.0, 0.5 );
    > var y = myCDF( 6.0 )
    ~0.801
    > y = myCDF( 2.0 )
    ~0.264

    If `α` or `β` is `NaN`, the function returns `NaN`.

        Rate parameter.

    -------

    > v = base.dists.gamma.entropy( 8.0, 2.0 )

base.dists.gamma.Gamma:
base.dists.gamma.Gamma( [α, β] )
    Returns a gamma distribution object.

    Parameters
    ----------
    α: number (optional)
        Shape parameter. Must be greater than `0`. Default: `1.0`.

    β: number (optional)
        Rate parameter. Must be greater than `0`. Default: `1.0`.

    Returns
    -------
    gamma: Object
        Distribution instance.

    gamma.alpha: number
        Shape parameter. If set, the value must be greater than `0`.

    gamma.beta: number
        Rate parameter. If set, the value must be greater than `0`.

    gamma.entropy: number
        Read-only property which returns the differential entropy.

    gamma.kurtosis: number
        Read-only property which returns the excess kurtosis.

    gamma.mean: number
        Read-only property which returns the expected value.

    gamma.mode: number
        Read-only property which returns the mode.

    gamma.skewness: number
        Read-only property which returns the skewness.

    gamma.stdev: number
        Read-only property which returns the standard deviation.

    gamma.variance: number
        Read-only property which returns the variance.

    gamma.cdf: Function
        Evaluates the cumulative distribution function (CDF).

    gamma.logpdf: Function
        Evaluates the natural logarithm of the probability density function
        (PDF).

    gamma.mgf: Function
        Evaluates the moment-generating function (MGF).

    gamma.pdf: Function
        Evaluates the probability density function (PDF).

    gamma.quantile: Function
        Evaluates the quantile function at probability `p`.

    Examples
    --------
    > var gamma = base.dists.gamma.Gamma( 6.0, 5.0 );
    > gamma.alpha
    6.0
    > gamma.beta
    5.0
    > gamma.entropy
    ~0.647
    > gamma.kurtosis
    1.0
    > gamma.mean
    1.2
    > gamma.mode
    1.0
    > gamma.skewness
    ~0.816
    > gamma.stdev
    ~0.49
    > gamma.variance
    0.24
    > gamma.cdf( 0.8 )
    ~0.215
    > gamma.logpdf( 1.0 )
    ~-0.131
    > gamma.mgf( -0.5 )
    ~0.564
    > gamma.pdf( 1.0 )
    ~0.877
    > gamma.quantile( 0.8 )
    ~1.581

    -Infinity
    > y = base.dists.gamma.logpdf( 0.0, 0.0, 2.0 )
    Infinity

base.dists.gamma.quantile:
base.dists.gamma.quantile( p, α, β )
    Evaluates the quantile function for a gamma distribution with shape
    parameter `α` and rate parameter `β` at a probability `p`.

    If `p < 0` or `p > 1`, the function returns `NaN`.

    If `α < 0` or `β <= 0`, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided `NaN` as any argument, the function returns `NaN`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    p: number
        Input probability.

    α: number
        Shape parameter.

    β: number
        Rate parameter.

    Returns
    -------
    out: number
        Evaluated quantile function.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.gamma.quantile( 0.8, 2.0, 1.0 )
    ~2.994
    > y = base.dists.gamma.quantile( 0.5, 4.0, 2.0 )
    ~1.836

    > y = base.dists.gamma.quantile( 1.1, 1.0, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.gamma.quantile( -0.2, 1.0, 1.0 )
    NaN

    > y = base.dists.gamma.quantile( NaN, 1.0, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.gamma.quantile( 0.0, NaN, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.gamma.quantile( 0.0, 1.0, NaN )
    NaN

    // Non-positive shape parameter:
    > y = base.dists.gamma.quantile( 0.5, -1.0, 1.0 )
    NaN
    // Non-positive rate parameter:
    > y = base.dists.gamma.quantile( 0.5, 1.0, -1.0 )
    NaN

    // Degenerate distribution centered at `0.0` when `α = 0.0`:
    > y = base.dists.gamma.quantile( 0.3, 0.0, 2.0 )
    0.0
    > y = base.dists.gamma.quantile( 0.9, 0.0, 2.0 )
    0.0

base.dists.geometric.Geometric:
base.dists.geometric.Geometric( [p] )
    Returns a geometric distribution object.

    Parameters
    ----------
    p: number (optional)
        Success probability. Must be between `0` and `1`. Default: `0.5`.

    Returns
    -------
    geometric: Object
        Distribution instance.

    geometric.p: number
        Success probability. If set, the value must be between `0` and `1`.

    geometric.entropy: number
        Read-only property which returns the differential entropy.

    geometric.kurtosis: number
        Read-only property which returns the excess kurtosis.

    geometric.mean: number
        Read-only property which returns the expected value.

    geometric.median: number
        Read-only property which returns the median.

    geometric.mode: number
        Read-only property which returns the mode.

    geometric.skewness: number
        Read-only property which returns the skewness.

    geometric.stdev: number
        Read-only property which returns the standard deviation.

    geometric.variance: number
        Read-only property which returns the variance.

    geometric.cdf: Function
        Evaluates the cumulative distribution function (CDF).

    geometric.logcdf: Function
        Evaluates the natural logarithm of the cumulative distribution function
        (CDF).

    geometric.logpmf: Function
        Evaluates the natural logarithm of the probability mass function (PMF).

    geometric.mgf: Function
        Evaluates the moment-generating function (MGF).

    geometric.pmf: Function
        Evaluates the probability mass function (PMF).

    geometric.quantile: Function
        Evaluates the quantile function at probability `p`.

    Examples
    --------
    > var geometric = base.dists.geometric.Geometric( 0.6 );
    > geometric.p
    0.6
    > geometric.entropy
    ~1.122
    > geometric.kurtosis
    ~6.9
    > geometric.mean
    ~0.667
    > geometric.median
    0.0
    > geometric.mode
    0.0
    > geometric.skewness
    ~2.214
    > geometric.stdev
    ~1.054
    > geometric.variance
    ~1.111
    > geometric.cdf( 3.0 )
    ~0.974
    > geometric.logcdf( 3.0 )
    ~-0.026
    > geometric.logpmf( 4.0 )
    ~-4.176
    > geometric.mgf( 0.5 )
    ~2.905
    > geometric.pmf( 2.0 )
    ~0.096
    > geometric.quantile( 0.7 )
    1.0

base.dists.geometric.mgf:
base.dists.geometric.mgf( t, p )
    Evaluates the moment-generating function (MGF) for a geometric
    distribution with success probability `p` at a value `t`.

    If provided `NaN` as any argument, the function returns `NaN`.

    If `p < 0` or `p > 1`, the function returns `NaN`.

    If `t >= -ln(1-p)`, the function returns `NaN`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    t: number
        Input value.

    p: number
        Success probability.

    Returns
    -------
    out: number
        Evaluated MGF.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.geometric.mgf( 0.2, 0.5 )
    ~1.569
    > y = base.dists.geometric.mgf( 0.4, 0.5 )
    ~2.936
    // Case: t >= -ln(1-p)
    > y = base.dists.geometric.mgf( 0.8, 0.5 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.geometric.mgf( NaN, 0.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.geometric.mgf( 0.0, NaN )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.geometric.mgf( -2.0, -1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.geometric.mgf( 0.2, 2.0 )
    NaN

base.dists.geometric.quantile:
base.dists.geometric.quantile( r, p )
    Evaluates the quantile function for a geometric distribution with success
    probability `p` at a probability `r`.

    If `r < 0` or `r > 1`, the function returns `NaN`.

    If `p < 0` or `p > 1`, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided `NaN` as any argument, the function returns `NaN`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    r: number
        Input probability.

    p: number
        Success probability.

    Returns
    -------
    out: number
        Evaluated quantile function.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.geometric.quantile( 0.8, 0.4 )
    3
    > y = base.dists.geometric.quantile( 0.5, 0.4 )
    1
    > y = base.dists.geometric.quantile( 0.9, 0.1 )
    21

    > y = base.dists.geometric.quantile( -0.2, 0.1 )
    NaN

    > y = base.dists.geometric.quantile( NaN, 0.8 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.geometric.quantile( 0.4, NaN )
    NaN

    > y = base.dists.geometric.quantile( 0.5, -1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.geometric.quantile( 0.5, 1.5 )
    NaN


base.dists.geometric.quantile.factory( p )
    Returns a function for evaluating the quantile function of a geometric
    distribution with success probability `p`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    p: number
        Success probability.

    Returns
    -------
    quantile: Function
        Quantile function.

    Examples
    --------
    > var myquantile = base.dists.geometric.quantile.factory( 0.4 );
    > var y = myquantile( 0.4 )
    0
    > y = myquantile( 0.8 )
    3
    > y = myquantile( 1.0 )
    Infinity

base.dists.gumbel.Gumbel:
base.dists.gumbel.Gumbel( [μ, β] )
    Returns a Gumbel distribution object.

    Parameters
    ----------
    μ: number (optional)
        Location parameter. Default: `0.0`.

    β: number (optional)
        Scale parameter. Must be greater than `0`. Default: `1.0`.

    Returns
    -------
    gumbel: Object
        Distribution instance.

    gumbel.mu: number
        Location parameter.

    gumbel.beta: number
        Scale parameter. If set, the value must be greater than `0`.

    gumbel.entropy: number
        Read-only property which returns the differential entropy.

    gumbel.kurtosis: number
        Read-only property which returns the excess kurtosis.

    gumbel.mean: number
        Read-only property which returns the expected value.

    gumbel.median: number
        Read-only property which returns the median.

    gumbel.mode: number
        Read-only property which returns the mode.

    gumbel.skewness: number
        Read-only property which returns the skewness.

    gumbel.stdev: number
        Read-only property which returns the standard deviation.

    gumbel.variance: number
        Read-only property which returns the variance.

    gumbel.cdf: Function
        Evaluates the cumulative distribution function (CDF).

    gumbel.logcdf: Function
        Evaluates the natural logarithm of the cumulative distribution function
        (CDF).

    gumbel.logpdf: Function
        Evaluates the natural logarithm of the probability density function
        (PDF).

    gumbel.mgf: Function
        Evaluates the moment-generating function (MGF).

    gumbel.pdf: Function
        Evaluates the probability density function (PDF).

    gumbel.quantile: Function
        Evaluates the quantile function at probability `p`.

    Examples
    --------
    > var gumbel = base.dists.gumbel.Gumbel( -2.0, 3.0 );
    > gumbel.mu
    -2.0
    > gumbel.beta
    3.0
    > gumbel.entropy
    ~2.676
    > gumbel.kurtosis
    2.4
    > gumbel.mean
    ~-0.268
    > gumbel.median
    ~-0.9
    > gumbel.mode
    -2.0
    > gumbel.skewness
    ~1.14
    > gumbel.stdev
    ~3.848
    > gumbel.variance
    ~14.804
    > gumbel.cdf( 0.8 )
    ~0.675
    > gumbel.logcdf( 0.8 )
    ~-0.393
    > gumbel.logpdf( 1.0 )
    ~-2.466
    > gumbel.mgf( 0.2 )
    ~1.487
    > gumbel.pdf( 1.0 )
    ~0.085
    > gumbel.quantile( 0.8 )
    ~2.5

base.dists.gumbel.quantile:
base.dists.gumbel.quantile( p, μ, β )
    Evaluates the quantile function for a Gumbel distribution with location
    parameter `μ` and scale parameter `β` at a probability `p`.

    If `p < 0` or `p > 1`, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided `NaN` as any argument, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided `β <= 0`, the function returns `NaN`.

    ----------

        Input probability.

    μ: number
        Location parameter.

    β: number
        Scale parameter.

    Returns
    -------
    out: number
        Evaluated quantile function.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.gumbel.quantile( 0.8, 0.0, 1.0 )
    ~1.5
    > y = base.dists.gumbel.quantile( 0.5, 4.0, 2.0 )
    ~4.733
    > y = base.dists.gumbel.quantile( 0.5, 4.0, 4.0 )
    ~5.466

    > y = base.dists.gumbel.quantile( 1.1, 0.0, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.gumbel.quantile( -0.2, 0.0, 1.0 )
    NaN

    > y = base.dists.gumbel.quantile( NaN, 0.0, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.gumbel.quantile( 0.0, NaN, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.gumbel.quantile( 0.0, 0.0, NaN )
    NaN

    // Negative scale parameter:
    > y = base.dists.gumbel.quantile( 0.5, 0.0, -1.0 )
    NaN

base.dists.hypergeometric.cdf:
base.dists.hypergeometric.cdf( x, N, K, n )
    Evaluates the cumulative distribution function (CDF) for a hypergeometric
    distribution with population size `N`, subpopulation size `K`, and number of
    draws `n` at a value `x`.

    If provided `NaN` as any argument, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided a population size `N`, subpopulation size `K` or draws `n` which
    is not a nonnegative integer, the function returns `NaN`.

    If the number of draws `n` or subpopulation size `K` exceeds population size
     `N`, the function returns `NaN`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    x: number
        Input value.

    N: integer
        Population size.

    K: integer
        Subpopulation size.

    n: integer
        Number of draws.

    Returns
    -------
    out: number
        Evaluated CDF.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.hypergeometric.cdf( 1.0, 8, 4, 2 )
    ~0.786
    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.cdf( 1.5, 8, 4, 2 )
    ~0.786
    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.cdf( 2.0, 8, 4, 2 )
    1.0
    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.cdf( 0, 8, 4, 2)
    ~0.214

    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.cdf( NaN, 10, 5, 2 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.cdf( 0.0, NaN, 5, 2 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.cdf( 0.0, 10, NaN, 2 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.cdf( 0.0, 10, 5, NaN )
    NaN

    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.cdf( 2.0, 10.5, 5, 2 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.cdf( 2.0, 10, 1.5, 2 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.cdf( 2.0, 10, 5, -2.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.cdf( 2.0, 10, 5, 12 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.cdf( 2.0, 8, 3, 9 )
    NaN


base.dists.hypergeometric.cdf.factory( N, K, n )
    Returns a function for evaluating the cumulative distribution function (CDF)
    of a hypergeometric distribution with population size `N`, subpopulation
    size `K`, and number of draws `n`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    N: integer
        Population size.

    K: integer
        Subpopulation size.

    n: integer
        Number of draws.

    Returns
    -------
    cdf: Function
        Cumulative distribution function (CDF).

    Examples

    > var myCDF = base.dists.hypergeometric.cdf.factory( 30, 20, 5 );

    ~0.031

base.dists.hypergeometric.Hypergeometric:
base.dists.hypergeometric.Hypergeometric( [N, K, n] )
    Returns a hypergeometric distribution object.

    Parameters
    ----------
    N: integer (optional)
        Population size. Must be a nonnegative integer larger than or equal to
        `K` and `n`.

    K: integer (optional)
        Subpopulation size. Must be a nonnegative integer smaller than or equal
        to `N`.

    n: integer (optional)
        Number of draws. Must be a nonnegative integer smaller than or equal to
        `N`.

    Returns
    -------
    hypergeometric: Object
        Distribution instance.

    hypergeometric.N: number
        Population size. If set, the value must be a nonnegative integer larger
        than or equal to `K` and `n`.

    hypergeometric.K: number
        Subpopulation size. If set, the value must be a nonnegative integer
        smaller than or equal to `N`.

    hypergeometric.n: number
        Number of draws. If set, the value must be a nonnegative integer
        smaller than or equal to `N`.

    hypergeometric.kurtosis: number
        Read-only property which returns the excess kurtosis.

    hypergeometric.mean: number
        Read-only property which returns the expected value.

    hypergeometric.mode: number
        Read-only property which returns the mode.

    hypergeometric.skewness: number
        Read-only property which returns the skewness.

    hypergeometric.stdev: number
        Read-only property which returns the standard deviation.

    hypergeometric.variance: number
        Read-only property which returns the variance.

    hypergeometric.cdf: Function
        Evaluates the cumulative distribution function (CDF).

    hypergeometric.logpmf: Function
        Evaluates the natural logarithm of the probability mass function (PMF).

    hypergeometric.pmf: Function
        Evaluates the probability mass function (PMF).

    hypergeometric.quantile: Function
        Evaluates the quantile function at probability `p`.

    Examples
    --------
    > var hypergeometric = base.dists.hypergeometric.Hypergeometric( 100, 70, 20 );
    > hypergeometric.N
    100.0
    > hypergeometric.K
    70.0
    > hypergeometric.n
    20.0
    > hypergeometric.kurtosis
    ~-0.063
    > hypergeometric.mean
    14.0
    > hypergeometric.mode
    14.0
    > hypergeometric.skewness
    ~-0.133
    > hypergeometric.stdev
    ~1.842
    > hypergeometric.variance
    ~3.394
    > hypergeometric.cdf( 2.9 )
    ~0.0
    > hypergeometric.logpmf( 10 )
    ~-3.806
    > hypergeometric.pmf( 10 )
    ~0.022
    > hypergeometric.quantile( 0.8 )
    16.0

base.dists.hypergeometric.logpmf:
base.dists.hypergeometric.logpmf( x, N, K, n )
    Evaluates the natural logarithm of the probability mass function (PMF) for a
    hypergeometric distribution with population size `N`, subpopulation size
    `K`, and number of draws `n` at a value `x`.

    If provided `NaN` as any argument, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided a population size `N`, subpopulation size `K`, or draws `n`
    which is not a nonnegative integer, the function returns `NaN`.

    If the number of draws `n` or the subpopulation size `K` exceed population
    size `N`, the function returns `NaN`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    x: number
        Input value.

    N: integer
        Population size.

    K: integer
        Subpopulation size.

    n: integer
        Number of draws.

    Returns
    -------
    out: number
        Evaluated logPMF.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.hypergeometric.logpmf( 1.0, 8, 4, 2 )
    ~-0.56
    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.logpmf( 2.0, 8, 4, 2 )
    ~-1.54
    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.logpmf( 0.0, 8, 4, 2 )
    ~-1.54
    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.logpmf( 1.5, 8, 4, 2 )
    -Infinity

    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.logpmf( NaN, 10, 5, 2 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.logpmf( 0.0, NaN, 5, 2 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.logpmf( 0.0, 10, NaN, 2 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.logpmf( 0.0, 10, 5, NaN )
    NaN

    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.logpmf( 2.0, 10.5, 5, 2 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.logpmf( 2.0, 5, 1.5, 2 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.logpmf( 2.0, 10, 5, -2.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.logpmf( 2.0, 10, 5, 12 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.logpmf( 2.0, 8, 3, 9 )
    NaN

base.dists.hypergeometric.quantile:
base.dists.hypergeometric.quantile( p, N, K, n )
    Evaluates the quantile function for a hypergeometric distribution with
    population size `N`, subpopulation size `K`, and number of draws `n` at a
    probability `p`.

    If `p < 0` or `p > 1`, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided `NaN` as any argument, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided a population size `N`, subpopulation size `K` or draws `n` which
    is not a nonnegative integer, the function returns `NaN`.

    If the number of draws `n` or the subpopulation size `K` exceed population
    size `N`, the function returns `NaN`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    p: number
        Input probability.

    N: integer
        Population size.

    K: integer
        Subpopulation size.

    n: integer
        Number of draws.

    Returns
    -------
    out: number
        Evaluated quantile function.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.hypergeometric.quantile( 0.4, 40, 20, 10 )
    5
    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.quantile( 0.8, 60, 40, 20 )
    15
    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.quantile( 0.5, 100, 10, 10 )
    1
    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.quantile( 0.0, 100, 40, 20 )
    0
    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.quantile( 1.0, 100, 40, 20 )
    20

    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.quantile( NaN, 40, 20, 10 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.quantile( 0.2, NaN, 20, 10 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.quantile( 0.2, 40, NaN, 10 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.hypergeometric.quantile( 0.2, 40, 20, NaN )
    NaN


base.dists.hypergeometric.quantile.factory( N, K, n )
    Returns a function for evaluating the quantile function of a hypergeometric
    distribution with population size `N`, subpopulation size `K`, and number of
    draws `n`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    N: integer
        Population size.

    K: integer
        Subpopulation size.

    n: integer
        Number of draws.

    Returns
    -------
    quantile: Function
        Quantile function.

    Examples
    --------
    > var myQuantile = base.dists.hypergeometric.quantile.factory( 100, 20, 10 );
    > var y = myQuantile( 0.2 )
    1
    > y = myQuantile( 0.9 )
    4

base.dists.invgamma.cdf:
base.dists.invgamma.cdf( x, α, β )
    Evaluates the cumulative distribution function (CDF) for an inverse gamma
    distribution with shape parameter `α` and scale parameter `β` at a value
    `x`.

    If `α <= 0` or `β <= 0`, the function returns `NaN`.

    If provided `NaN` as any argument, the function returns `NaN`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    x: number
        Input value.

    α: number
        Shape parameter.

    β: number
        Scale parameter.

    Returns
    -------
    out: number
        Evaluated CDF.

    Examples
    --------
    > var y = base.dists.invgamma.cdf( 2.0, 1.0, 1.0 )
    ~0.607
    > y = base.dists.invgamma.cdf( 2.0, 3.0, 1.0 )
    ~0.986
    > y = base.dists.invgamma.cdf( -1.0, 2.0, 2.0 )
    0.0
    > y = base.dists.invgamma.cdf( PINF, 4.0, 2.0 )
    1.0
    > y = base.dists.invgamma.cdf( NINF, 4.0, 2.0 )
    0.0

    > y = base.dists.invgamma.cdf( NaN, 0.0, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.invgamma.cdf( 0.0, NaN, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.invgamma.cdf( 0.0, 0.0, NaN )
    NaN

    > y = base.dists.invgamma.cdf( 2.0, -1.0, 1.0 )
    NaN
    > y = base.dists.invgamma.cdf( 2.0, 1.0, -1.0 )
    NaN
