instanceOf:
instanceOf( value, constructor )
    Tests whether a value has in its prototype chain a specified constructor as
    a prototype property.

    While the prototype of an `object` created using object literal notion is
    `undefined`, the function returns `true` when provided an `object` literal
    and the `Object` constructor. This maintains consistent behavior with the
    `instanceof` operator.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Input value.

    constructor: Function
        Constructor.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating if a value is an instance of a provided constructor.

    Examples
    --------
    > var bool = instanceOf( [], Array )
    true
    > bool = instanceOf( {}, Object )
    true
    > bool = instanceOf( null, Object )
    false

    See Also
    --------
    isPrototypeOf, constructorName, inherit, typeOf
INT8_MAX:
INT8_MAX
    Maximum signed 8-bit integer.

    The maximum signed 8-bit integer is given by `2^7 - 1`.

    Examples
    --------
    > INT8_MAX
    127

    See Also
    --------
    INT8_MIN
INT8_MIN:
INT8_MIN
    Minimum signed 8-bit integer.

    The minimum signed 8-bit integer is given by `-(2^7)`.

    Examples
    --------
    > INT8_MIN
    -128

    See Also
    --------
    INT8_MAX
INT8_NUM_BYTES:
INT8_NUM_BYTES
    Size (in bytes) of an 8-bit signed integer.

    Examples
    --------
    > INT8_NUM_BYTES
    1

    See Also
    --------
    INT16_NUM_BYTES, INT32_NUM_BYTES, UINT8_NUM_BYTES
Int8Array:
Int8Array()
    A typed array constructor which returns a typed array representing an array
    of twos-complement 8-bit signed integers in the platform byte order.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Int8Array
        A typed array.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array()
    <Int8Array>


Int8Array( length )
    Returns a typed array having a specified length.

    Parameters
    ----------
    length: integer
        Typed array length.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Int8Array
        A typed array.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( 5 )
    <Int8Array>[ 0, 0, 0, 0, 0 ]


Int8Array( typedarray )
    Creates a typed array from another typed array.

    Parameters
    ----------
    typedarray: TypedArray
        Typed array from which to generate another typed array.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Int8Array
        A typed array.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr1 = new Int32Array( [ 5, 5, 5 ] );
    > var arr2 = new Int8Array( arr1 )
    <Int8Array>[ 5, 5, 5 ]


Int8Array( obj )
    Creates a typed array from an array-like object or iterable.

    Parameters
    ----------
    obj: Object
        Array-like object or iterable from which to generate a typed array.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Int8Array
        A typed array.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr1 = [ 5.0, 5.0, 5.0 ];
    > var arr2 = new Int8Array( arr1 )
    <Int8Array>[ 5, 5, 5 ]


Int8Array( buffer[, byteOffset[, length]] )
    Returns a typed array view of an ArrayBuffer.

    Parameters
    ----------
    buffer: ArrayBuffer
        Underlying ArrayBuffer.

    byteOffset: integer (optional)
        Integer byte offset specifying the location of the first typed array
        element. Default: 0.

    length: integer (optional)
        View length. If not provided, the view spans from the byteOffset to
        the end of the underlying ArrayBuffer.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Int8Array
        A typed array.

    Examples
    --------
    > var buf = new ArrayBuffer( 4 );
    > var arr = new Int8Array( buf, 0, 4 )
    <Int8Array>[ 0, 0, 0, 0 ]


Int8Array.from( src[, map[, thisArg]] )
    Creates a new typed array from an array-like object or an iterable.

    A callback is provided the following arguments:

    - value: source value.
    - index: source index.

    Parameters
    ----------
    src: ArrayLike|Iterable
        Source of array elements.

    map: Function (optional)
        Callback to invoke for each source element.

    thisArg: Any (optional)
        Callback execution context.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Int8Array
        A typed array.

    Examples
    --------
    > function mapFcn( v ) { return v * 2; };
    > var arr = Int8Array.from( [ 1, 2 ], mapFcn )
    <Int8Array>[ 2, 4 ]


Int8Array.of( element0[, element1[, ...elementN]] )
    Creates a new typed array from a variable number of arguments.

    Parameters
    ----------
    element0: number
        Array element.

    element1: number (optional)
        Array element.

    elementN: number (optional)
        Array elements.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Int8Array
        A typed array.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = Int8Array.of( 1, 2 )
    <Int8Array>[ 1, 2 ]


Int8Array.BYTES_PER_ELEMENT
    Number of bytes per view element.

    Examples
    --------
    > Int8Array.BYTES_PER_ELEMENT
    1


Int8Array.name
    Typed array constructor name.

    Examples
    --------
    > Int8Array.name
    'Int8Array'


Int8Array.prototype.buffer
    Read-only property which returns the ArrayBuffer referenced by the typed
    array.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( 5 );
    > arr.buffer
    <ArrayBuffer>


Int8Array.prototype.byteLength
    Read-only property which returns the length (in bytes) of the typed array.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( 5 );
    > arr.byteLength
    5


Int8Array.prototype.byteOffset
    Read-only property which returns the offset (in bytes) of the typed array
    from the start of its ArrayBuffer.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( 5 );
    > arr.byteOffset
    0


Int8Array.prototype.BYTES_PER_ELEMENT
    Number of bytes per view element.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( 5 );
    > arr.BYTES_PER_ELEMENT
    1


Int8Array.prototype.length
    Read-only property which returns the number of view elements.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( 5 );
    > arr.length
    5


Int8Array.prototype.copyWithin( target, start[, end] )
    Copies a sequence of elements within the array starting at `start` and
    ending at `end` (non-inclusive) to the position starting at `target`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    target: integer
        Target start index position.

    start: integer
        Source start index position.

    end: integer (optional)
        Source end index position. Default: out.length.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Int8Array
        Modified array.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( [ 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 ] );
    > arr.copyWithin( 3, 0, 2 );
    > arr[ 3 ]
    1
    > arr[ 4 ]
    2


Int8Array.prototype.entries()
    Returns an iterator for iterating over array key-value pairs.

    Returns
    -------
    iter: Iterator
        Iterator for iterating over array key-value pairs.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( [ 1, 2 ] );
    > it = arr.entries();
    > it.next().value
    [ 0, 1 ]
    > it.next().value
    [ 1, 2 ]
    > it.next().done
    true


Int8Array.prototype.every( predicate[, thisArg] )
    Tests whether all array elements pass a test implemented by a predicate
    function.

    A predicate function is provided the following arguments:

    - value: array element.
    - index: array index.
    - arr: array on which the method is invoked.

    Parameters
    ----------
    predicate: Function
        Predicate function which tests array elements. If a predicate function
        returns a truthy value, an array element passes; otherwise, an array
        element fails.

    thisArg: Any (optional)
        Callback execution context.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating whether all array elements pass.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( [ 1, 2 ] );
    > function predicate( v ) { return ( v <= 1 ); };
    > arr.every( predicate )
    false


Int8Array.prototype.fill( value[, start[, end]] )
    Fills an array from a start index to an end index (non-inclusive) with a
    provided value.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: number
        Fill value.

    start: integer (optional)
        Start index. If less than zero, the start index is resolved relative to
        the last array element. Default: 0.

    end: integer (optional)
        End index (non-inclusive). If less than zero, the end index is resolved
        relative to the last array element. Default: out.length.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Int8Array
        Modified array.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( [ 1, 2 ] );
    > arr.fill( 3 );
    > arr[ 0 ]
    3
    > arr[ 1 ]
    3


Int8Array.prototype.filter( predicate[, thisArg] )
    Creates a new array which includes those elements for which a predicate
    function returns a truthy value.

    A predicate function is provided the following arguments:

    - value: array element.
    - index: array index.
    - arr: array on which the method is invoked.

    The returned array has the same data type as the host array.

    If a predicate function does not return a truthy value for any array
    element, the method returns `null`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    predicate: Function
        Predicate function which filters array elements. If a predicate function
        returns a truthy value, an array element is included in the output
        array; otherwise, an array element is not included in the output array.

    thisArg: Any (optional)
        Callback execution context.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Int8Array
        A typed array.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr1 = new Int8Array( [ 1, 2, 3 ] );
    > function predicate( v ) { return ( v > 1 ); };
    > var arr2 = arr1.filter( predicate );
    > arr2.length
    2


Int8Array.prototype.find( predicate[, thisArg] )
    Returns the first array element for which a provided predicate function
    returns a truthy value.

    A predicate function is provided the following arguments:

    - value: array element.
    - index: array index.
    - arr: array on which the method is invoked.

    If a predicate function never returns a truthy value, the method returns
    `undefined`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    predicate: Function
        Predicate function which tests array elements.

    thisArg: Any (optional)
        Callback execution context.

    Returns
    -------
    value: number|undefined
        Array element.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( [ 1, 2, 3 ] );
    > function predicate( v ) { return ( v > 2 ); };
    > var v = arr.find( predicate )
    3


Int8Array.prototype.findIndex( predicate[, thisArg] )
    Returns the index of the first array element for which a provided predicate
    function returns a truthy value.

    A predicate function is provided the following arguments:

    - value: array element.
    - index: array index.
    - arr: array on which the method is invoked.

    If a predicate function never returns a truthy value, the method returns
    `-1`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    predicate: Function
        Predicate function which tests array elements.

    thisArg: Any (optional)
        Callback execution context.

    Returns
    -------
    idx: integer
        Array index.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( [ 1, 2, 3 ] );
    > function predicate( v ) { return ( v > 2 ); };
    > var idx = arr.findIndex( predicate )
    2


Int8Array.prototype.forEach( fcn[, thisArg] )
    Invokes a callback for each array element.

    A provided function is provided the following arguments:

    - value: array element.
    - index: array index.
    - arr: array on which the method is invoked.

    Parameters
    ----------
    fcn: Function
        Function to invoke for each array element.

    thisArg: Any (optional)
        Callback execution context.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( [ 3, 2, 1 ] );
    > var str = ' ';
    > function fcn( v, i ) { str += i + ':' + v + ' '; };
    > arr.forEach( fcn );
    > str
    ' 0:3 1:2 2:1 '


Int8Array.prototype.includes( searchElement[, fromIndex] )
    Returns a boolean indicating whether an array includes a search element.

    Parameters
    ----------
    searchElement: number
        Search element.

    fromIndex: integer (optional)
        Array index from which to begin searching. If provided a negative value,
        the method resolves the start index relative to the last array element.
        Default: 0.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating whether an array includes a search element.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( [ 1, 2, 3 ] );
    > var bool = arr.includes( 4 )
    false
    > bool = arr.includes( 3 )
    true


Int8Array.prototype.indexOf( searchElement[, fromIndex] )
    Returns the index of the first array element strictly equal to a search
    element.

    If unable to locate a search element, the method returns `-1`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    searchElement: number
        Search element.

    fromIndex: integer (optional)
        Array index from which to begin searching. If provided a negative value,
        the method resolves the start index relative to the last array element.
        Default: 0.

    Returns
    -------
    idx: integer
        Array index.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( [ 1, 2, 3 ] );
    > var idx = arr.indexOf( 4 )
    -1
    > idx = arr.indexOf( 3 )
    2


Int8Array.prototype.join( [separator] )
    Serializes an array by joining all array elements as a string.

    Parameters
    ----------
    separator: string (optional)
        String delineating array elements. Default: ','.

    Returns
    -------
    str: string
        Array serialized as a string.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( [ 1, 2, 3 ] );
    > arr.join( '|' )
    '1|2|3'


Int8Array.prototype.keys()
    Returns an iterator for iterating over array keys.

    Returns
    -------
    iter: Iterator
        Iterator for iterating over array keys.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( [ 1, 2 ] );
    > it = arr.keys();
    > it.next().value
    0
    > it.next().value
    1
    > it.next().done
    true


Int8Array.prototype.lastIndexOf( searchElement[, fromIndex] )
    Returns the index of the last array element strictly equal to a search
    element.

    The method iterates from the last array element to the first array element.

    If unable to locate a search element, the method returns `-1`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    searchElement: number
        Search element.

    fromIndex: integer (optional)
        Array index from which to begin searching. If provided a negative value,
        the method resolves the start index relative to the last array element.
        Default: -1.

    Returns
    -------
    idx: integer
        array index.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( [ 1, 0, 2, 0, 1 ] );
    > var idx = arr.lastIndexOf( 3 )
    -1
    > idx = arr.lastIndexOf( 0 )
    3


Int8Array.prototype.map( fcn[, thisArg] )
    Maps each array element to an element in a new typed array.

    A provided function is provided the following arguments:

    - value: array element.
    - index: array index.
    - arr: array on which the method is invoked.

    The returned array has the same data type as the host array.

    Parameters
    ----------
    fcn: Function
        Function which maps array elements to elements in the new array.

    thisArg: Any (optional)
        Callback execution context.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Int8Array
        A typed array.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr1 = new Int8Array( [ 1, 2, 3 ] );
    > function fcn( v ) { return v * 2; };
    > var arr2 = arr1.map( fcn );
    <Int8Array>[ 2, 4, 6 ]


Int8Array.prototype.reduce( fcn[, initialValue] )
    Applies a function against an accumulator and each element in an array and
    returns the accumulated result.

    The provided function is provided the following arguments:

    - acc: accumulated result.
    - value: current array element.
    - index: index of the current array element.
    - arr: array on which the method is invoked.

    If provided an initial value, the method invokes a provided function with
    the initial value as the first argument and the first array element as the
    second argument.

    If not provided an initial value, the method invokes a provided function
    with the first array element as the first argument and the second array
    element as the second argument.

    Parameters
    ----------
    fcn: Function
        Function to apply.

    initialValue: Any (optional)
        Initial accumulation value.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Any
        Accumulated result.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( [ 1, 2, 3 ] );
    > function fcn( acc, v ) { return acc + (v*v); };
    > var v = arr.reduce( fcn, 0 )
    14


Int8Array.prototype.reduceRight( fcn[, initialValue] )
    Applies a function against an accumulator and each element in an array and
    returns the accumulated result, iterating from right to left.

    The provided function is provided the following arguments:

    - acc: accumulated result.
    - value: current array element.
    - index: index of the current array element.
    - arr: array on which the method is invoked.

    If provided an initial value, the method invokes a provided function with
    the initial value as the first argument and the last array element as the
    second argument.

    If not provided an initial value, the method invokes a provided function
    with the last array element as the first argument and the second-to-last
    array element as the second argument.

    Parameters
    ----------
    fcn: Function
        Function to apply.

    initialValue: Any (optional)
        Initial accumulation value.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Any
        Accumulated result.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( [ 1, 2, 3 ] );
    > function fcn( acc, v ) { return acc + (v*v); };
    > var v = arr.reduceRight( fcn, 0 )
    14


Int8Array.prototype.reverse()
    Reverses an array *in-place*.

    This method mutates the array on which the method is invoked.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Int8Array
        Modified array.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( [ 1, 2, 3 ] )
    <Int8Array>[ 1, 2, 3 ]
    > arr.reverse()
    <Int8Array>[ 3, 2, 1 ]


Int8Array.prototype.set( arr[, offset] )
    Sets array elements.

    Parameters
    ----------
    arr: ArrayLike
        Source array containing array values to set.

    offset: integer (optional)
        Array index at which to start writing values. Default: 0.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( [ 1, 2, 3 ] );
    > arr.set( [ 4, 4 ], 1 );
    > arr[ 1 ]
    4
    > arr[ 2 ]
    4


Int8Array.prototype.slice( [begin[, end]] )
    Copies array elements to a new array with the same underlying data type as
    the host array.

    If the method is unable to resolve indices to a non-empty array subsequence,
    the method returns `null`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    begin: integer (optional)
        Start element index (inclusive). If less than zero, the start index is
        resolved relative to the last array element. Default: 0.

    end: integer (optional)
        End element index (exclusive). If less than zero, the end index is
        resolved relative to the last array element. Default: arr.length.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Int8Array
        A typed array.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr1 = new Int8Array( [ 1, 2, 3 ] );
    > var arr2 = arr1.slice( 1 );
    > arr2.length
    2
    > arr2[ 0 ]
    1
    > arr2[ 1 ]
    2


Int8Array.prototype.some( predicate[, thisArg] )
    Tests whether at least one array element passes a test implemented by a
    predicate function.

    A predicate function is provided the following arguments:

    - value: array element.
    - index: array index.
    - arr: array on which the method is invoked.

    Parameters
    ----------
    predicate: Function
        Predicate function which tests array elements. If a predicate function
        returns a truthy value, a array element passes; otherwise, an array
        element fails.

    thisArg: Any (optional)
        Callback execution context.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating whether at least one array element passes.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( [ 1, 2 ] );
    > function predicate( v ) { return ( v > 1 ); };
    > arr.some( predicate )
    true


Int8Array.prototype.sort( [compareFunction] )
    Sorts an array *in-place*.

    The comparison function is provided two array elements per invocation: `a`
    and `b`.

    The comparison function return value determines the sort order as follows:

    - If the comparison function returns a value less than zero, then the method
    sorts `a` to an index lower than `b` (i.e., `a` should come *before* `b`).

    - If the comparison function returns a value greater than zero, then the
    method sorts `a` to an index higher than `b` (i.e., `b` should come *before*
    `a`).

    - If the comparison function returns zero, then the relative order of `a`
    and `b` should remain unchanged.

    This method mutates the array on which the method is invoked.

    Parameters
    ----------
    compareFunction: Function (optional)
        Function which specifies the sort order. The default sort order is
        ascending order.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Int8Array
        Modified array.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( [ 1, 2, 0, 2, 1 ] );
    > arr.sort()
    <Int8Array>[ 0, 1, 1, 2, 2 ]


Int8Array.prototype.subarray( [begin[, end]] )
    Creates a new typed array over the same underlying ArrayBuffer and with the
    same underlying data type as the host array.

    If the method is unable to resolve indices to a non-empty array subsequence,
    the method returns an empty typed array.

    Parameters
    ----------
    begin: integer (optional)
        Start element index (inclusive). If less than zero, the start index is
        resolved relative to the last array element. Default: 0.

    end: integer (optional)
        End element index (exclusive). If less than zero, the end index is
        resolved relative to the last array element. Default: arr.length.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Int8Array
        A new typed array view.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr1 = new Int8Array( [ 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 ] );
    > var arr2 = arr1.subarray( 2 )
    <Int8Array>[ 3, 4, 5 ]


Int8Array.prototype.toLocaleString( [locales[, options]] )
    Serializes an array as a locale-specific string.

    Parameters
    ----------
    locales: string|Array<string> (optional)
        A BCP 47 language tag, or an array of such tags.

    options: Object (optional)
        Options.

    Returns
    -------
    str: string
        A typed array string representation.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( [ 1, 2, 3 ] );
    > arr.toLocaleString()
    '1,2,3'


Int8Array.prototype.toString()
    Serializes an array as a string.

    Returns
    -------
    str: string
        A typed array string representation.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( [ 1, 2, 3 ] );
    > arr.toString()
    '1,2,3'


Int8Array.prototype.values()
    Returns an iterator for iterating over array elements.

    Returns
    -------
    iter: Iterator
        Iterator for iterating over array elements.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( [ 1, 2 ] );
    > it = arr.values();
    > it.next().value
    1
    > it.next().value
    2
    > it.next().done
    true


    See Also
    --------
    ArrayBuffer, Float32Array, Float64Array, Int16Array, Int32Array, Uint16Array, Uint32Array, Uint8Array, Uint8ClampedArray

Int8Array.prototype.entries()

Int8Array.prototype.filter:
Int8Array.prototype.filter( predicate[, thisArg] )
    Creates a new array which includes those elements for which a predicate
    function returns a truthy value.

    A predicate function is provided the following arguments:

    - value: array element.
    - index: array index.
    - arr: array on which the method is invoked.

    The returned array has the same data type as the host array.

    If a predicate function does not return a truthy value for any array
    element, the method returns `null`.

    ----------

        returns a truthy value, an array element is included in the output
        array; otherwise, an array element is not included in the output array.

    thisArg: Any (optional)

    Returns
    -------
    out: Int8Array
        A typed array.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr1 = new Int8Array( [ 1, 2, 3 ] );
    > function predicate( v ) { return ( v > 1 ); };
    > var arr2 = arr1.filter( predicate );
    > arr2.length
    2

Int8Array.prototype.reduce:
Int8Array.prototype.reduce( fcn[, initialValue] )
    Applies a function against an accumulator and each element in an array and
    returns the accumulated result.

    The provided function is provided the following arguments:

    - acc: accumulated result.
    - value: current array element.
    - index: index of the current array element.
    - arr: array on which the method is invoked.

    If provided an initial value, the method invokes a provided function with
    the initial value as the first argument and the first array element as the
    second argument.

    If not provided an initial value, the method invokes a provided function
    with the first array element as the first argument and the second array
    element as the second argument.

    Parameters
    ----------
    fcn: Function
        Function to apply.

    initialValue: Any (optional)
        Initial accumulation value.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Any
        Accumulated result.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( [ 1, 2, 3 ] );
    > function fcn( acc, v ) { return acc + (v*v); };
    > var v = arr.reduce( fcn, 0 )
    14
Int8Array.prototype.reduceRight:
Int8Array.prototype.reduceRight( fcn[, initialValue] )
    Applies a function against an accumulator and each element in an array and
    returns the accumulated result, iterating from right to left.

    The provided function is provided the following arguments:

    - acc: accumulated result.
    - value: current array element.
    - index: index of the current array element.
    - arr: array on which the method is invoked.

    If provided an initial value, the method invokes a provided function with
    the initial value as the first argument and the last array element as the
    second argument.

    If not provided an initial value, the method invokes a provided function
    with the last array element as the first argument and the second-to-last
    array element as the second argument.

    Parameters
    ----------
    fcn: Function
        Function to apply.

    initialValue: Any (optional)
        Initial accumulation value.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Any
        Accumulated result.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( [ 1, 2, 3 ] );
    > function fcn( acc, v ) { return acc + (v*v); };
    > var v = arr.reduceRight( fcn, 0 )
    14

    - arr: array on which the method is invoked.

Int8Array.prototype.sort:
Int8Array.prototype.sort( [compareFunction] )
    Sorts an array *in-place*.

    The comparison function is provided two array elements per invocation: `a`
    and `b`.

    The comparison function return value determines the sort order as follows:

    - If the comparison function returns a value less than zero, then the method
    sorts `a` to an index lower than `b` (i.e., `a` should come *before* `b`).

    - If the comparison function returns a value greater than zero, then the
    method sorts `a` to an index higher than `b` (i.e., `b` should come *before*
    `a`).

    - If the comparison function returns zero, then the relative order of `a`
    and `b` should remain unchanged.

    This method mutates the array on which the method is invoked.

    Parameters
    ----------
    compareFunction: Function (optional)
        Function which specifies the sort order. The default sort order is
        ascending order.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Int8Array
        Modified array.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int8Array( [ 1, 2, 0, 2, 1 ] );
    > arr.sort()
    <Int8Array>[ 0, 1, 1, 2, 2 ]
Int8Array.prototype.subarray:

    same underlying data type as the host array.

        resolved relative to the last array element. Default: 0.

    Returns

        A new typed array view.

    Examples

    > var arr1 = new Int8Array( [ 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 ] );
    > var arr2 = arr1.subarray( 2 )
    <Int8Array>[ 3, 4, 5 ]

Int16Array.prototype.map( fcn[, thisArg] )
    Maps each array element to an element in a new typed array.

    - value: array element.
    - index: array index.
    - arr: array on which the method is invoked.

    The returned array has the same data type as the host array.

Int16Array.prototype.reduce( fcn[, initialValue] )
    Applies a function against an accumulator and each element in an array and
    returns the accumulated result.

    The provided function is provided the following arguments:

    - acc: accumulated result.
    - value: current array element.
    - index: index of the current array element.
    - arr: array on which the method is invoked.

    If provided an initial value, the method invokes a provided function with
    the initial value as the first argument and the first array element as the
    second argument.

    If not provided an initial value, the method invokes a provided function
    with the first array element as the first argument and the second array
    element as the second argument.

    Parameters
    ----------
    fcn: Function
        Function to apply.

    initialValue: Any (optional)
        Initial accumulation value.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Any
        Accumulated result.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int16Array( [ 1, 2, 3 ] );
    > function fcn( acc, v ) { return acc + (v*v); };
    > var v = arr.reduce( fcn, 0 )
    14


Int16Array.prototype.reduceRight( fcn[, initialValue] )
    Applies a function against an accumulator and each element in an array and
    returns the accumulated result, iterating from right to left.

    The provided function is provided the following arguments:

    - acc: accumulated result.
    - value: current array element.
    - index: index of the current array element.
    - arr: array on which the method is invoked.

    If provided an initial value, the method invokes a provided function with
    the initial value as the first argument and the last array element as the
    second argument.

    If not provided an initial value, the method invokes a provided function
    with the last array element as the first argument and the second-to-last
    array element as the second argument.

    Parameters
    ----------
    fcn: Function
        Function to apply.

    initialValue: Any (optional)
        Initial accumulation value.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Any
        Accumulated result.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int16Array( [ 1, 2, 3 ] );
    > function fcn( acc, v ) { return acc + (v*v); };
    > var v = arr.reduceRight( fcn, 0 )
    14

Int16Array.prototype.some( predicate[, thisArg] )
    Tests whether at least one array element passes a test implemented by a
    predicate function.

    A predicate function is provided the following arguments:

    - value: array element.
    - index: array index.
    - arr: array on which the method is invoked.

    Parameters

    predicate: Function
        Predicate function which tests array elements. If a predicate function
        returns a truthy value, a array element passes; otherwise, an array
        element fails.

    thisArg: Any (optional)

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating whether at least one array element passes.

    Examples

    > function predicate( v ) { return ( v > 1 ); };
    > arr.some( predicate )
    true


Int16Array.prototype.sort( [compareFunction] )
    Sorts an array *in-place*.

    The comparison function is provided two array elements per invocation: `a`
    and `b`.

    The comparison function return value determines the sort order as follows:

    - If the comparison function returns a value less than zero, then the method
    sorts `a` to an index lower than `b` (i.e., `a` should come *before* `b`).

    - If the comparison function returns a value greater than zero, then the
    method sorts `a` to an index higher than `b` (i.e., `b` should come *before*
    `a`).

    - If the comparison function returns zero, then the relative order of `a`
    and `b` should remain unchanged.

    This method mutates the array on which the method is invoked.

    Parameters
    ----------
    compareFunction: Function (optional)
        Function which specifies the sort order. The default sort order is
        ascending order.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Int16Array
        Modified array.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int16Array( [ 1, 2, 0, 2, 1 ] );
    > arr.sort()
    <Int16Array>[ 0, 1, 1, 2, 2 ]


Int16Array.prototype.subarray( [begin[, end]] )
    Creates a new typed array over the same underlying ArrayBuffer and with the
    same underlying data type as the host array.

    the method returns an empty typed array.

    begin: integer (optional)
        Start element index (inclusive). If less than zero, the start index is
        resolved relative to the last array element. Default: 0.

    end: integer (optional)
        End element index (exclusive). If less than zero, the end index is
        resolved relative to the last array element. Default: arr.length.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Int16Array
        A new typed array view.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr1 = new Int16Array( [ 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 ] );
    > var arr2 = arr1.subarray( 2 )
    <Int16Array>[ 3, 4, 5 ]

    > var arr1 = new Int16Array( [ 1, 2, 3 ] );
    > function fcn( v ) { return v * 2; };
    > var arr2 = arr1.map( fcn );
    <Int16Array>[ 2, 4, 6 ]
Int16Array.prototype.reduce:
Int16Array.prototype.reduce( fcn[, initialValue] )
    Applies a function against an accumulator and each element in an array and
    returns the accumulated result.

    The provided function is provided the following arguments:

    - acc: accumulated result.
    - value: current array element.
    - index: index of the current array element.
    - arr: array on which the method is invoked.

    If provided an initial value, the method invokes a provided function with
    the initial value as the first argument and the first array element as the
    second argument.

    If not provided an initial value, the method invokes a provided function
    with the first array element as the first argument and the second array
    element as the second argument.

    Parameters
    ----------
    fcn: Function
        Function to apply.

    initialValue: Any (optional)
        Initial accumulation value.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Any
        Accumulated result.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int16Array( [ 1, 2, 3 ] );
    > function fcn( acc, v ) { return acc + (v*v); };
    > var v = arr.reduce( fcn, 0 )
    14
Int16Array.prototype.reduceRight:
Int16Array.prototype.reduceRight( fcn[, initialValue] )
    Applies a function against an accumulator and each element in an array and
    returns the accumulated result, iterating from right to left.

    The provided function is provided the following arguments:

    - acc: accumulated result.
    - value: current array element.
    - index: index of the current array element.
    - arr: array on which the method is invoked.

    If provided an initial value, the method invokes a provided function with
    the initial value as the first argument and the last array element as the
    second argument.

    If not provided an initial value, the method invokes a provided function
    with the last array element as the first argument and the second-to-last
    array element as the second argument.

    Parameters
    ----------
    fcn: Function
        Function to apply.

    initialValue: Any (optional)
        Initial accumulation value.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Any
        Accumulated result.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int16Array( [ 1, 2, 3 ] );
    > function fcn( acc, v ) { return acc + (v*v); };
    > var v = arr.reduceRight( fcn, 0 )
    14
Int16Array.prototype.reverse:
Int16Array.prototype.reverse()
    Reverses an array *in-place*.

    This method mutates the array on which the method is invoked.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Int16Array
        Modified array.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int16Array( [ 1, 2, 3 ] )
    <Int16Array>[ 1, 2, 3 ]
    > arr.reverse()
    <Int16Array>[ 3, 2, 1 ]
Int16Array.prototype.set:
Int16Array.prototype.set( arr[, offset] )
    Sets array elements.

    Parameters
    ----------
    arr: ArrayLike
        Source array containing array values to set.

    offset: integer (optional)
        Array index at which to start writing values. Default: 0.

    Examples
    --------

    > arr.set( [ 4, 4 ], 1 );
    > arr[ 1 ]
    4
    > arr[ 2 ]
    4
Int16Array.prototype.slice:
Int16Array.prototype.slice( [begin[, end]] )
    Copies array elements to a new array with the same underlying data type as
    the host array.

    If the method is unable to resolve indices to a non-empty array subsequence,
    the method returns `null`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    begin: integer (optional)
        Start element index (inclusive). If less than zero, the start index is
        resolved relative to the last array element. Default: 0.

    end: integer (optional)
        End element index (exclusive). If less than zero, the end index is
        resolved relative to the last array element. Default: arr.length.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Int16Array
        A typed array.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr1 = new Int16Array( [ 1, 2, 3 ] );
    > var arr2 = arr1.slice( 1 );
    > arr2.length
    2
    > arr2[ 0 ]
    1
    > arr2[ 1 ]
    2
Int16Array.prototype.some:
Int16Array.prototype.some( predicate[, thisArg] )
    Tests whether at least one array element passes a test implemented by a
    predicate function.

    A predicate function is provided the following arguments:

    - value: array element.
    - index: array index.
    - arr: array on which the method is invoked.

    Parameters
    ----------
    predicate: Function
        Predicate function which tests array elements. If a predicate function
        returns a truthy value, a array element passes; otherwise, an array
        element fails.

    thisArg: Any (optional)
        Callback execution context.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating whether at least one array element passes.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int16Array( [ 1, 2 ] );
    > function predicate( v ) { return ( v > 1 ); };
    > arr.some( predicate )
    true
Int16Array.prototype.sort:
Int16Array.prototype.sort( [compareFunction] )
    Sorts an array *in-place*.

    The comparison function is provided two array elements per invocation: `a`
    and `b`.

    The comparison function return value determines the sort order as follows:

    - If the comparison function returns a value less than zero, then the method
    sorts `a` to an index lower than `b` (i.e., `a` should come *before* `b`).

    - If the comparison function returns a value greater than zero, then the
    method sorts `a` to an index higher than `b` (i.e., `b` should come *before*
    `a`).

    - If the comparison function returns zero, then the relative order of `a`
    and `b` should remain unchanged.

    This method mutates the array on which the method is invoked.

    Parameters
    ----------
    compareFunction: Function (optional)
        Function which specifies the sort order. The default sort order is
        ascending order.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Int16Array
        Modified array.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int16Array( [ 1, 2, 0, 2, 1 ] );
    > arr.sort()
    <Int16Array>[ 0, 1, 1, 2, 2 ]
Int16Array.prototype.subarray:
Int16Array.prototype.subarray( [begin[, end]] )
    Creates a new typed array over the same underlying ArrayBuffer and with the
    same underlying data type as the host array.

    If the method is unable to resolve indices to a non-empty array subsequence,
    the method returns an empty typed array.

    Parameters
    ----------
    begin: integer (optional)
        Start element index (inclusive). If less than zero, the start index is
        resolved relative to the last array element. Default: 0.

    end: integer (optional)
        End element index (exclusive). If less than zero, the end index is
        resolved relative to the last array element. Default: arr.length.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Int16Array
        A new typed array view.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr1 = new Int16Array( [ 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 ] );
    > var arr2 = arr1.subarray( 2 )
    <Int16Array>[ 3, 4, 5 ]

    Applies a function against an accumulator and each element in an array and

    The provided function is provided the following arguments:

    - acc: accumulated result.
    - value: current array element.

    > function fcn( acc, v ) { return acc + (v*v); };

    second argument.

    If not provided an initial value, the method invokes a provided function
    with the last array element as the first argument and the second-to-last
    array element as the second argument.

    initialValue: Any (optional)

    Returns

    > function fcn( acc, v ) { return acc + (v*v); };

        resolved relative to the last array element. Default: 0.

    -------
    out: Int32Array

Int32Array.prototype.some( predicate[, thisArg] )
    Tests whether at least one array element passes a test implemented by a
    predicate function.

    A predicate function is provided the following arguments:

    - value: array element.
    - index: array index.
    - arr: array on which the method is invoked.

    Parameters
    ----------
    predicate: Function
        Predicate function which tests array elements. If a predicate function
        returns a truthy value, a array element passes; otherwise, an array
        element fails.

        Callback execution context.

    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating whether at least one array element passes.

Int32Array.prototype.sort( [compareFunction] )
    Sorts an array *in-place*.

    The comparison function is provided two array elements per invocation: `a`
    and `b`.

    The comparison function return value determines the sort order as follows:

    - If the comparison function returns a value less than zero, then the method
    sorts `a` to an index lower than `b` (i.e., `a` should come *before* `b`).

    - If the comparison function returns a value greater than zero, then the
    method sorts `a` to an index higher than `b` (i.e., `b` should come *before*
    `a`).

    - If the comparison function returns zero, then the relative order of `a`
    and `b` should remain unchanged.

    This method mutates the array on which the method is invoked.

    Parameters
    ----------
    compareFunction: Function (optional)
        Function which specifies the sort order. The default sort order is
        ascending order.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Int32Array
        Modified array.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int32Array( [ 1, 2, 0, 2, 1 ] );
    > arr.sort()
    <Int32Array>[ 0, 1, 1, 2, 2 ]

    Creates a new typed array over the same underlying ArrayBuffer and with the
    same underlying data type as the host array.

    the method returns an empty typed array.

        resolved relative to the last array element. Default: 0.

    end: integer (optional)

        resolved relative to the last array element. Default: arr.length.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Int32Array
        A new typed array view.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr1 = new Int32Array( [ 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 ] );
    > var arr2 = arr1.subarray( 2 )
    <Int32Array>[ 3, 4, 5 ]

Int32Array.prototype.reduce:
Int32Array.prototype.reduce( fcn[, initialValue] )
    Applies a function against an accumulator and each element in an array and
    returns the accumulated result.

    The provided function is provided the following arguments:

    - acc: accumulated result.
    - value: current array element.
    - index: index of the current array element.
    - arr: array on which the method is invoked.

    If provided an initial value, the method invokes a provided function with
    the initial value as the first argument and the first array element as the
    second argument.

    If not provided an initial value, the method invokes a provided function
    with the first array element as the first argument and the second array
    element as the second argument.

    Parameters
    ----------
    fcn: Function
        Function to apply.

    initialValue: Any (optional)
        Initial accumulation value.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Any
        Accumulated result.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int32Array( [ 1, 2, 3 ] );
    > function fcn( acc, v ) { return acc + (v*v); };
    > var v = arr.reduce( fcn, 0 )
    14
Int32Array.prototype.reduceRight:
Int32Array.prototype.reduceRight( fcn[, initialValue] )
    Applies a function against an accumulator and each element in an array and
    returns the accumulated result, iterating from right to left.

    The provided function is provided the following arguments:

    - acc: accumulated result.
    - value: current array element.
    - index: index of the current array element.
    - arr: array on which the method is invoked.

    If provided an initial value, the method invokes a provided function with
    the initial value as the first argument and the last array element as the
    second argument.

    If not provided an initial value, the method invokes a provided function
    with the last array element as the first argument and the second-to-last
    array element as the second argument.

    Parameters
    ----------
    fcn: Function
        Function to apply.

    initialValue: Any (optional)
        Initial accumulation value.

    Returns
    -------
    out: Any
        Accumulated result.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = new Int32Array( [ 1, 2, 3 ] );
    > function fcn( acc, v ) { return acc + (v*v); };
    > var v = arr.reduceRight( fcn, 0 )
    14

isAbsolutePath:
isAbsolutePath( value )
    Tests if a value is an absolute path.

    Function behavior is platform-specific. On Windows platforms, the function
    is equal to `.win32()`. On POSIX platforms, the function is equal to
    `.posix()`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating if a value is an absolute path.

    Examples
    --------
    // Windows environment:
    > var bool = isAbsolutePath( 'C:\\foo\\bar\\baz' )
    true

    // POSIX environment:
    > bool = isAbsolutePath( '/foo/bar/baz' )
    true


isAbsolutePath.posix( value )
    Tests if a value is a POSIX absolute path.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating if a value is a POSIX absolute path.

    Examples
    --------
    > var bool = isAbsolutePath.posix( '/foo/bar/baz' )
    true
    > bool = isAbsolutePath.posix( 'foo/bar/baz' )
    false


isAbsolutePath.win32( value )
    Tests if a value is a Windows absolute path.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating if a value is a Windows absolute path.

    Examples
    --------
    > var bool = isAbsolutePath.win32( 'C:\\foo\\bar\\baz' )
    true
    > bool = isAbsolutePath.win32( 'foo\\bar\\baz' )
    false

    See Also
    --------
    isRelativePath

isAccessorProperty:
isAccessorProperty( value, property )
    Tests if an object's own property has an accessor descriptor.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    property: any
        Property to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating if an object's own property has an accessor
        descriptor.

    Examples
    --------
    > var obj = { 'boop': true };
    > var desc = {};
    > desc.configurable = false;
    > desc.enumerable = false;
    > desc.get = function getter() { return 'beep'; };
    > defineProperty( obj, 'beep', desc );
    > var bool = isAccessorProperty( obj, 'boop' )
    false
    > bool = isAccessorProperty( obj, 'beep' )
    true

    See Also
    --------
    hasOwnProp, isAccessorPropertyIn, isDataProperty
isAccessorPropertyIn:
isAccessorPropertyIn( value, property )
    Tests if an object's own or inherited property has an accessor descriptor.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    property: any
        Property to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating if an object's own or inherited property has an
        accessor descriptor.

    Examples
    --------
    > var obj = { 'boop': true };
    > var desc = {};
    > desc.configurable = false;
    > desc.enumerable = false;
    > desc.get = function getter() { return 'beep'; };
    > defineProperty( obj, 'beep', desc );
    > var bool = isAccessorPropertyIn( obj, 'boop' )
    false
    > bool = isAccessorPropertyIn( obj, 'beep' )
    true

    See Also
    --------
    hasProp, isAccessorProperty, isDataPropertyIn
isAlphagram:
isAlphagram( value )
    Tests if a value is an alphagram (i.e., a sequence of characters arranged in
    alphabetical order).

    The function first checks that an input value is a string before validating
    that the value is an alphagram. For non-string values, the function returns
    `false`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating whether value is an alphagram.

    Examples
    --------
    > var out = isAlphagram( 'beep' )
    true
    > out = isAlphagram( 'zba' )
    false
    > out = isAlphagram( '' )
    false

    See Also
    --------
    isAnagram

        Boolean indicating whether a string contains only alphanumeric
        characters.

    Examples
    --------
    > var bool = isAlphaNumeric( 'abc0123456789' )
    true
    > bool = isAlphaNumeric( 'abcdef' )
    true
    > bool = isAlphaNumeric( '0xff' )

    > bool = isAlphaNumeric( '' )
    false

    See Also

    false

isArrayLength:
isArrayLength( value )
    Tests if a value is a valid array length.

    A valid length property for an Array instance is any integer value on the
    interval [0, 2^32-1].

    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating whether value is a valid array length.

    Examples
    --------
    > var bool = isArrayLength( 5 )
    true
    > bool = isArrayLength( 2.0e200 )
    false
    > bool = isArrayLength( -3.14 )
    false
    > bool = isArrayLength( null )
    false

    See Also
    --------
    isArray

isBetween:
isBetween( value, a, b[, left, right] )
    Tests if a value is between two values.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Input value.

    a: any
        Left comparison value.

    b: any
        Right comparison value.

    left: string (optional)
        Indicates whether the left comparison value is inclusive. Must be either
        'closed' or 'open'. Default: 'closed' (i.e., inclusive).

    right: string (optional)
        Indicates whether the right comparison value is inclusive. Must be
        either 'closed' or 'open'. Default: 'closed' (i.e., inclusive).

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating whether a value is between two values.

    Examples
    --------
    > var bool = isBetween( 3.14, 3.0, 4.0 )
    true
    > bool = isBetween( 3.0, 3.0, 4.0 )
    true
    > bool = isBetween( 4.0, 3.0, 4.0 )
    true
    > bool = isBetween( 3.0, 3.14, 4.0 )
    false
    > bool = isBetween( 3.14, 3.14, 4.0, 'open', 'closed' )
    false
    > bool = isBetween( 3.14, 3.0, 3.14, 'closed', 'open' )
    false

    See Also
    --------
    isBetweenArray
isBetweenArray:
isBetweenArray( value, a, b[, left, right] )
    Tests if a value is an array-like object where every element is between two
    values.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Input value.

    a: any
        Left comparison value.

    b: any
        Right comparison value.

    left: string (optional)
        Indicates whether the left comparison value is inclusive. Must be either
        'closed' or 'open'. Default: 'closed' (i.e., inclusive).

    right: string (optional)
        Indicates whether the right comparison value is inclusive. Must be
        either 'closed' or 'open'. Default: 'closed' (i.e., inclusive).

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating whether a value is an array-like object where every
        element is between two values.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = [ 3.0, 3.14, 4.0 ];
    > var bool = isBetweenArray( arr, 3.0, 4.0 )
    true
    > bool = isBetweenArray( arr, 3.14, 4.0 )
    false
    > bool = isBetweenArray( arr, 3.0, 3.14 )
    false
    > bool = isBetweenArray( arr, 3.0, 4.0, 'open', 'closed' )
    false
    > bool = isBetweenArray( arr, 3.0, 4.0, 'closed', 'open' )
    false

    See Also
    --------
    isBetween

    > var bool = isComplex128( new Complex128( 3.0, 1.0 ) )
    true
    > bool = isComplex128( new Complex64( 2.0, 2.0 ) )
    false
    > bool = isComplex128( 3.14 )
    false
    > bool = isComplex128( {} )
    false

    See Also
    --------
    isComplex, isComplex64

isConfigurableProperty:
isConfigurableProperty( value, property )
    Tests if an object's own property is configurable.

    A property is configurable if the property may be deleted or its descriptor
    may be changed.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    property: any
        Property to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating if an object's own property is configurable.

    Examples
    --------
    > var obj = { 'boop': true };
    > var desc = {};
    > desc.configurable = false;
    > desc.enumerable = true;
    > desc.writable = true;
    > desc.value = true;
    > defineProperty( obj, 'beep', desc );
    > var bool = isConfigurableProperty( obj, 'boop' )
    true
    > bool = isConfigurableProperty( obj, 'beep' )
    false

    See Also
    --------
    isConfigurablePropertyIn, isEnumerableProperty, isReadableProperty, isWritableProperty
isConfigurablePropertyIn:
isConfigurablePropertyIn( value, property )
    Tests if an object's own or inherited property is configurable.

    A property is configurable if the property may be deleted or its descriptor
    may be changed.

    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    property: any
        Property to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating if an object's own or inherited property is
        configurable.

    Examples
    --------
    > var obj = { 'boop': true };
    > var desc = {};
    > desc.configurable = false;
    > desc.enumerable = true;
    > desc.writable = true;
    > desc.value = true;
    > defineProperty( obj, 'beep', desc );
    > var bool = isConfigurablePropertyIn( obj, 'boop' )
    true
    > bool = isConfigurablePropertyIn( obj, 'beep' )
    false

    See Also
    --------
    isConfigurableProperty, isEnumerablePropertyIn, isReadablePropertyIn, isWritablePropertyIn

    Returns

    bool: boolean

    > var obj = { 'boop': true };
    > var desc = {};
    > desc.configurable = false;
    > desc.enumerable = false;
    > desc.get = function getter() { return 'beep'; };
    > defineProperty( obj, 'beep', desc );

isEmailAddress:
isEmailAddress( value )
    Tests if a value is an email address.

    Validation is not rigorous. *9* RFCs relate to email addresses, and
    accounting for all of them is a fool's errand. The function performs the
    simplest validation; i.e., requiring at least one `@` symbol.

    For rigorous validation, send a confirmation email. If the email bounces,
    consider the email invalid.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating whether value is an email address.

    Examples
    --------
    > var bool = isEmailAddress( 'beep@boop.com' )
    true
    > bool = isEmailAddress( 'beep' )
    false
    > bool = isEmailAddress( null )
    false

isEvalError:
isEvalError( value )
    Tests if a value is an EvalError object.

    This function should *not* be considered robust. While the function should
    always return `true` if provided an EvalError (or a descendant) object,
    false positives may occur due to the fact that the EvalError constructor
    inherits from Error and has no internal class of its own. Hence, EvalError
    impersonation is possible.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating whether value is an EvalError object.

    Examples
    --------
    > var bool = isEvalError( new EvalError( 'beep' ) )
    true
    > bool = isEvalError( {} )
    false

    See Also
    --------
    isError

    ----------

        Input string.

    -------

    Examples

isIterableLike:
isIterableLike( value )
    Tests if a value is iterable-like.

    In order to be iterable, an object must implement the @@iterator method,
    which, when called, returns an iterator protocol-compliant object.

    An iterator protocol-compliant object is an object having a `next` method
    which adheres to the iterator protocol.

    As full iterator compliance is impossible to achieve without evaluating an
    iterator, this function checks *only* for interface compliance.

    In environments lacking Symbol.iterator support, this function always
    returns `false`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating whether value is iterable-like.

    Examples
    --------
    > var bool = isIterableLike( [ 1, 2, 3 ] )
    <boolean>
    > bool = isIterableLike( {} )
    false
    > bool = isIterableLike( null )
    false

    See Also
    --------
    isIteratorLike
isIteratorLike:
isIteratorLike( value )
    Tests if a value is iterator-like.

    An iterator protocol-compliant object is an object having a `next` method
    which adheres to the iterator protocol.

    As full iterator compliance is impossible to achieve without evaluating an
    iterator, this function checks *only* for interface compliance.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating whether value is iterator-like.

    Examples
    --------
    > var obj = {
    ...     'next': function noop() {}
    ... };
    > var bool = isIteratorLike( obj )
    true
    > bool = isIteratorLike( {} )
    false
    > bool = isIteratorLike( null )
    false

    See Also
    --------
    isIterableLike

isLeapYear:
isLeapYear( value )
    Tests whether a value corresponds to a leap year in the Gregorian calendar.

    A leap year is defined as any year which is exactly divisible by 4, except
    for years which are exactly divisible by 100 and not by 400. In this
    definition, 100 corresponds to years marking a new century, and 400
    corresponds to the length of the *leap cycle*.

    If not provided any arguments, the function returns a boolean indicating
    if the current year (according to local time) is a leap year.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating whether value corresponds to a leap year.

    Examples
    --------
    > var bool = isLeapYear( new Date() )
    <boolean>
    > bool = isLeapYear( 1996 )
    true
    > bool = isLeapYear( 2001 )
    false

isMethod:
isMethod( value, property )
    Tests if an object has a specified method name.

    Value arguments other than `null` or `undefined` are coerced to objects.

    Property arguments are coerced to strings.

    The function only searches own properties.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    property: any
        Property to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating if an object has a specified method name.

    Examples
    --------
    > var beep = { 'boop': function beep() { return 'beep'; } };
    > var bool = isMethod( beep, 'boop' )
    true
    > bool = isMethod( beep, 'toString' )
    false

    See Also
    --------
    hasOwnProp, isFunction, isMethodIn

isNonConfigurableProperty:
isNonConfigurableProperty( value, property )
    Tests if an object's own property is non-configurable.

    A non-configurable property is a property which cannot be deleted and whose
    descriptor cannot be changed.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    property: any
        Property to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating if an object's own property is non-configurable.

    Examples
    --------
    > var obj = { 'boop': true };
    > var desc = {};
    > desc.configurable = false;
    > desc.enumerable = true;
    > desc.writable = true;
    > desc.value = 'beep';
    > defineProperty( obj, 'beep', desc );
    > var bool = isNonConfigurableProperty( obj, 'boop' )
    false
    > bool = isNonConfigurableProperty( obj, 'beep' )
    true

    See Also
    --------
    isConfigurableProperty, isEnumerableProperty, isNonConfigurablePropertyIn, isNonEnumerableProperty, isReadableProperty, isWritableProperty
isNonConfigurablePropertyIn:
isNonConfigurablePropertyIn( value, property )
    Tests if an object's own or inherited property is non-configurable.

    A non-configurable property is a property which cannot be deleted and whose
    descriptor cannot be changed.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    property: any
        Property to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating if an object's own or inherited property is non-
        configurable.

    Examples
    --------
    > var obj = { 'boop': true };
    > var desc = {};
    > desc.configurable = false;
    > desc.enumerable = true;
    > desc.writable = true;
    > desc.value = true;
    > defineProperty( obj, 'beep', desc );
    > var bool = isNonConfigurablePropertyIn( obj, 'boop' )
    false
    > bool = isNonConfigurablePropertyIn( obj, 'beep' )
    true

    See Also
    --------
    isConfigurablePropertyIn, isEnumerablePropertyIn, isNonConfigurableProperty, isNonEnumerablePropertyIn, isReadablePropertyIn, isWritablePropertyIn

isoWeeksInYear:
isoWeeksInYear( [year] )
    Returns the number of ISO weeks in a year according to the Gregorian
    calendar.

    By default, the function returns the number of ISO weeks in the current year
    (according to local time). To determine the number of ISO weeks for a
    particular year, provide either a year or a `Date` object.

    Parameters
    ----------
    year: integer (optional)
        Year.

    Returns
    -------
    out: integer
        Number of ISO weeks in a year.

    Examples
    --------
    > var num = isoWeeksInYear()
    <number>
    > num = isoWeeksInYear( 2015 )
    53
    > num = isoWeeksInYear( 2017 )
    52

    --------
    > var mat = ndarray( 'generic', 2 );
    > var M = mat( [ 1, 2, 3, 1 ], [ 2, 2 ], [ 2, 1 ], 0, 'row-major' );
    > var bool = isPersymmetricMatrix( M )
    true
    > bool = isPersymmetricMatrix( [ 1, 2, 3, 4 ] )
    false
    > bool = isPersymmetricMatrix( 3.14 )
    false
    > bool = isPersymmetricMatrix( {} )
    false

    See Also
    --------
    isMatrixLike, isSquareMatrix, isSymmetricMatrix

isPrototypeOf:
isPrototypeOf( value, proto )
    Tests if an object's prototype chain contains a provided prototype.

    The function returns `false` if provided a primitive value.

    This function is generally more robust than the `instanceof` operator (e.g.,
    where inheritance is performed without using constructors).

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Input value.

    proto: Object|Function
        Prototype.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating if a provided prototype exists in a prototype chain.

    Examples
    --------
    > function Foo() { return this; };
    > function Bar() { return this; };
    > inherit( Bar, Foo );
    > var bar = new Bar();
    > var bool = isPrototypeOf( bar, Foo.prototype )
    true

    See Also
    --------
    getPrototypeOf
isRangeError:
isRangeError( value )
    Tests if a value is a RangeError object.

    This function should *not* be considered robust. While the function should
    always return `true` if provided a RangeError (or a descendant) object,
    false positives may occur due to the fact that the RangeError constructor
    inherits from Error and has no internal class of its own. Hence, RangeError
    impersonation is possible.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating whether value is a RangeError object.

    Examples
    --------
    > var bool = isRangeError( new RangeError( 'beep' ) )
    true
    > bool = isRangeError( {} )
    false

    See Also
    --------
    isError
isReadableProperty:
isReadableProperty( value, property )
    Tests if an object's own property is readable.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    property: any
        Property to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating if an object's own property is readable.

    Examples
    --------
    > var obj = { 'boop': true };
    > var desc = {};
    > desc.configurable = false;
    > desc.enumerable = false;
    > desc.set = function setter( v ) { obj.boop = v; };
    > defineProperty( obj, 'beep', desc );
    > var bool = isReadableProperty( obj, 'boop' )
    true
    > bool = isReadableProperty( obj, 'beep' )
    false

    See Also
    --------
    isReadOnlyProperty, isReadWriteProperty, isReadablePropertyIn, isWritableProperty

    > desc.set = function setter( v ) { obj.boop = v; };
    > defineProperty( obj, 'beep', desc );
    > var bool = isReadablePropertyIn( obj, 'boop' )
    true

    > var obj = { 'boop': true };
    > var desc = {};
    > desc.configurable = false;
    > desc.enumerable = true;
    > desc.writable = false;
    > desc.value = true;
    > defineProperty( obj, 'beep', desc );
    > var bool = isReadOnlyProperty( obj, 'boop' )
    true
    > bool = isReadOnlyProperty( obj, 'beep' )
    false

    See Also
    --------
    isReadOnlyPropertyIn, isReadWriteProperty, isReadableProperty, isWritableProperty
isReadOnlyPropertyIn:

    > desc.writable = false;
    > desc.value = true;
    > defineProperty( obj, 'beep', desc );

isReferenceError:
isReferenceError( value )
    Tests if a value is a ReferenceError object.

    This function should *not* be considered robust. While the function should
    always return `true` if provided a ReferenceError (or a descendant)
    object, false positives may occur due to the fact that the ReferenceError
    constructor inherits from Error and has no internal class of its own.
    Hence, ReferenceError impersonation is possible.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating whether value is a ReferenceError object.

    Examples
    --------
    > var bool = isReferenceError( new ReferenceError( 'beep' ) )
    true
    > bool = isReferenceError( {} )
    false

    See Also
    --------
    isError

    value: any

    Examples

    > var bool = isRegExp( /\.+/ )
    true
    > bool = isRegExp( {} )
    false

    > bool = isRegExpString( '' )
    false
    > bool = isRegExpString( null )
    false

    See Also

isRelativePath:
isRelativePath( value )
    Tests if a value is a relative path.

    Function behavior is platform-specific. On Windows platforms, the function
    is equal to `.win32()`. On POSIX platforms, the function is equal to
    `.posix()`.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating whether value is a relative path.

    Examples
    --------
    // Windows environments:
    > var bool = isRelativePath( 'foo\\bar\\baz' )
    true

    // POSIX environments:
    > bool = isRelativePath( './foo/bar/baz' )
    true


isRelativePath.posix( value )
    Tests if a value is a POSIX relative path.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating whether value is a POSIX relative path.

    Examples
    --------
    > var bool = isRelativePath.posix( './foo/bar/baz' )
    true
    > bool = isRelativePath.posix( '/foo/../bar/baz' )
    false


isRelativePath.win32( value )
    Tests if a value is a Windows relative path.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating whether value is a Windows relative path.

    Examples
    --------
    > var bool = isRelativePath( 'foo\\bar\\baz' )
    true
    > bool = isRelativePath( 'C:\\foo\\..\\bar\\baz' )
    false

    See Also
    --------
    isAbsolutePath

isSafeInteger:
isSafeInteger( value )
    Tests if a value is a safe integer.

    An integer valued number is "safe" when the number can be exactly
    represented as a double-precision floating-point number.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating whether value is a safe integer.

    Examples
    --------
    > var bool = isSafeInteger( 5.0 )
    true
    > bool = isSafeInteger( new Number( 5.0 ) )
    true
    > bool = isSafeInteger( 2.0e200 )
    false
    > bool = isSafeInteger( -3.14 )
    false
    > bool = isSafeInteger( null )
    false


isSafeInteger.isPrimitive( value )
    Tests if a value is a number primitive having a safe integer value.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating whether value is a number primitive having a safe
        integer value.

    Examples
    --------
    > var bool = isSafeInteger.isPrimitive( -3.0 )
    true
    > bool = isSafeInteger.isPrimitive( new Number( -3.0 ) )
    false


isSafeInteger.isObject( value )
    Tests if a value is a `Number` object having a safe integer value.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating whether value is a `Number` object having a safe
        integer value.

    Examples
    --------
    > var bool = isSafeInteger.isObject( 3.0 )
    false
    > bool = isSafeInteger.isObject( new Number( 3.0 ) )
    true

    See Also
    --------
    isInteger, isNumber

isSafeIntegerArray:
isSafeIntegerArray( value )
    Tests if a value is an array-like object containing only safe integers.

    An integer valued number is "safe" when the number can be exactly
    represented as a double-precision floating-point number.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating whether value is an array-like object containing
        only safe integers.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = [ -3.0, new Number(0.0), 2.0 ];
    > var bool = isSafeIntegerArray( arr )
    true
    > arr = [ -3.0, '3.0' ];
    > bool = isSafeIntegerArray( arr )
    false

    integer values.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating whether value is an array-like object containing only
        primitive safe integer values.

    Examples
    --------
    > var arr = [ -1.0, 10.0 ];
    > var bool = isSafeIntegerArray.primitives( arr )
    true
    > arr = [ -1.0, 0.0, 5.0 ];
    > bool = isSafeIntegerArray.primitives( arr )
    true
    > arr = [ -3.0, new Number(-1.0) ];
    > bool = isSafeIntegerArray.primitives( arr )
    false

    --------
    > var arr = [ new Number(1.0), new Number(3.0) ];
    > var bool = isSafeIntegerArray.objects( arr )
    true
    > arr = [ -1.0, 0.0, 3.0 ];
    > bool = isSafeIntegerArray.objects( arr )
    false
    > arr = [ 3.0, new Number(-1.0) ];
    > bool = isSafeIntegerArray.objects( arr )
    false

isSameValue:
isSameValue( a, b )
    Tests if two arguments are the same value.

    The function differs from the `===` operator in that the function treats
    `-0` and `+0` as distinct and `NaNs` as the same.

    Parameters
    ----------
    a: any
        First input value.

    b: any
        Second input value.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating whether two arguments are the same value.

    Examples
    --------
    > var bool = isSameValue( true, true )
    true
    > bool = isSameValue( {}, {} )
    false
    > bool = isSameValue( -0.0, -0.0 )
    true
    > bool = isSameValue( -0.0, 0.0 )
    false
    > bool = isSameValue( NaN, NaN )
    true

    See Also
    --------
    isSameValueZero, isStrictEqual
isSameValueZero:
isSameValueZero( a, b )
    Tests if two arguments are the same value.

    The function differs from the `===` operator in that the function treats
    `NaNs` as the same.

        First input value.

    b: any
        Second input value.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating whether two arguments are the same value.

    Examples
    --------
    > var bool = isSameValueZero( true, true )
    true
    > bool = isSameValueZero( {}, {} )
    false
    > bool = isSameValueZero( -0.0, -0.0 )
    true
    > bool = isSameValueZero( -0.0, 0.0 )
    true
    > bool = isSameValueZero( NaN, NaN )
    true

    See Also
    --------
    isSameValue, isStrictEqual

isSkewCentrosymmetricMatrix:

    Examples
    --------
    > var mat = ndarray( 'generic', 2 );
    > var M = mat( [ 2, 1, -1, -2 ], [ 2, 2 ], [ 2, 1 ], 0, 'row-major' );

    true
    > bool = isSkewCentrosymmetricMatrix( [ 1, 2, 3, 4 ] )
    false
    > bool = isSkewCentrosymmetricMatrix( 3.14 )
    false
    > bool = isSkewCentrosymmetricMatrix( {} )
    false

    primitives.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean

        only `symbol` primitives.

    Examples
    --------

    false

    false

    Examples
    --------
    > var bool = isURI( 'http://google.com' )
    true
    > bool = isURI( 'http://localhost/' )
    true
    > bool = isURI( 'http://example.w3.org/path%20with%20spaces.html' )
    true
    > bool = isURI( 'ftp://ftp.is.co.za/rfc/rfc1808.txt' )
    true

    // No scheme:
    > bool = isURI( '' )
    false
    > bool = isURI( 'foo@bar' )
    false
    > bool = isURI( '://foo/' )
    false

    // Illegal characters:
    > bool = isURI( 'http://<foo>' )
    false

    // Invalid path:
    > bool = isURI( 'http:////foo.html' )
    false

    // Incomplete hex escapes:
    > bool = isURI( 'http://example.w3.org/%a' )
    false

isWhitespace:
isWhitespace( str )
    Tests whether a string contains only white space characters.

    A white space character is defined as one of the 25 characters defined as a
    white space ("WSpace=Y","WS") character in the Unicode 9.0 character
    database, as well as one related white space character without the Unicode
    character property "WSpace=Y" (zero width non-breaking space which was
    deprecated as of Unicode 3.2).

    Parameters
    ----------
    str: string
        Input string.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating whether a string contains only white space
        characters.

    Examples
    --------
    > var bool = isWhitespace( '       ' )
    true
    > bool = isWhitespace( 'abcdef' )
    false
    > bool = isWhitespace( '' )
    false

    See Also
    --------
    RE_WHITESPACE
isWritableProperty:
isWritableProperty( value, property )
    Tests if an object's own property is writable.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value: any
        Value to test.

    property: any
        Property to test.

    Returns
    -------
    bool: boolean
        Boolean indicating if an object's own property is writable.

    Examples
    --------
    > var obj = { 'boop': true };
    > var desc = {};
    > desc.configurable = false;
    > desc.enumerable = false;
    > desc.writable = false;
    > desc.value = 'beep';
    > defineProperty( obj, 'beep', desc );
    > var bool = isWritableProperty( obj, 'boop' )
    true
    > bool = isWritableProperty( obj, 'beep' )
    false

    See Also
    --------
    isReadableProperty, isReadWriteProperty, isWritablePropertyIn, isWriteOnlyProperty
